title: Bills could finally tumble if Britain cuts 'bonkers' red tape, says Octopus boss - The Sun
description:
ENERGY bills could finally tumble if Britain cuts “bonkers” red tape costing customer a fortune, the boss of Octopus has claimed.
Greg Jackson — founder of the energy technology company — says families are being “played” by a system riddled with waste.
He warned: “We desperately need energy bills to fall.
The Octopus Energy chief explained: “Firstly, they’re becoming more affordable.
If ministers cut the rot he predicts a brighter future where green tech delivers energy independence, economic growth and lower family bills.
text:
ENERGY bills could finally tumble if Britain cuts “bonkers” red tape costing customer a fortune, the boss of Octopus has claimed.

Greg Jackson — founder of the energy technology company — says families are being “played” by a system riddled with waste.

That includes £100million spent on a bat tunnel for the HS2 rail route and £700million on “fish disco” protection measures at Hinkley Point C nuclear power station in Somerset.

In a rallying cry for common sense in 2026, the tycoon insists the path to lower inflation and cheaper power rests in stripping away over-regulation and bureaucracy.

He warned: “We desperately need energy bills to fall.

“This will only happen if the Government gets tough on big companies gaming the system.

“It means ending bonkers stuff like paying wind farms over £1billion to turn off on windy days.”

But, despite that waste, he insists the world is moving away from oil and gas towards green energy technology.

The Octopus Energy chief explained: “Firstly, they’re becoming more affordable. Just three years ago, gas prices sent bills sky high and trashed our economy.

“As long as we’re hooked on them, we’re at the mercy of dictators and foreign governments.

“More from the North Sea may help — but it’s a drop in the ocean and won’t save us from these forces.

“Secondly, electric technologies just keep getting better. The cost of solar, batteries and electric cars is plummeting. When you buy gas from Qatar it’s gone the moment you burn it. Solar panels generate power for decades.”

Mr Jackson also called for a return to old-fashioned customer service in this age of AI.

He urged firms to start answering the phone instead of hiding behind “crappy systems and computers that say no”.

That — and slashing costs added to bills to fund infrastructure “we don’t need” — is the only way to get the economy moving again.

If ministers cut the rot he predicts a brighter future where green tech delivers energy independence, economic growth and lower family bills.

A future of fakeaways

SHOPPERS are mixing budget basics with posh treats to beat the cost-of-living crunch.

Sainsbury’s CEO Simon Roberts reckons 2026 will be the year of the “fakeaway” — as families ditch pricy restaurants for premium meals at home.

He said: “Dining out has become more expensive so our premium ranges are really popular. More customers will choose restaurant quality food at home.”

He said the big weekly shop is back in fashion as people flock back to work.

And he vowed to back British farmers and use hi-tech loyalty apps to give ­customers the “tailored experiences” they will crave this year.

Bank on Cups

PUB landlords are banking on a World Cup bonanza to save them from a Budget tax nightmare.

Star Pubs’ boss Lawson Mountstevens said: “If you can’t be at the game, nothing beats watching it at your local with a delicious pint.”

Meanwhile Stella David, boss of Ladbrokes owner Entain, said the “extremely high tax increases” could threaten high-street bookies and drive punters to use black-market operators.

Hol tax fear

SUN-loving Brits are rushing to book their 2026 getaways, but face a looming tax threat.

Low-cost airline Jet2, which will launch flights from London Gatwick in March, is warning the Government not to treat holidays as if they’re a luxury for the wealthy.

Boss Steve Heapy has blasted “punitive” taxes on the industry and called for urgent support for sustainable aviation fuel.

title: This Airline Had The World's Largest Widebody Fleet In 2025 - Simple Flying
authors: Josh Eyre, Jacob Johnson, Jake Hardiman
description:
Introduction To Emirates Emirates is the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, based in Dubai.
Established in 1985 with a fleet of just two aircraft, Emirates experienced rapid growth by continuously expanding its route network and investing in modern aircraft.
The airline operates the world’s largest widebody fleet, featuring Airbus A380s and Boeing 777s, which support efficient operations on high-demand international routes.
From advanced baggage handling systems to modern lounges and spacious boarding gates, Dubai International Airport combines efficiency with luxury.
Fleet Overview Emirates currently operates the world’s largest widebody fleet, dominated by the Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 families.
text:
Emirates is the flag carrier airline of the United Arab Emirates, headquartered in the city of Dubai. Since its founding in 1985, the airline has grown from a small operation with just two aircraft into one of the most recognized names in global aviation. Known for its focus on long-haul international travel and premium service, Emirates has built a reputation for reliability, luxury, and innovation. Its strategic location in Dubai allows it to connect passengers efficiently across Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas, making it a key player in global air travel.

The airline operates an all-widebody fleet, including iconic aircraft such as the Airbus A380 and Boeing 777, allowing it to carry large numbers of passengers on long-haul routes. Emirates continues to invest in modern aircraft and innovative technology to enhance the travel experience, from advanced in-flight entertainment to onboard connectivity options. With a commitment to quality, global connectivity, and passenger comfort, Emirates remains a leader in international aviation while expanding its network and modernizing its fleet for the future.

Introduction To Emirates

Emirates is the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, based in Dubai. Since its launch, it has become one of the most prominent airlines in the world, playing a key role in connecting destinations across continents and serving as a bridge between Eastern and Western markets.

Established in 1985 with a fleet of just two aircraft, Emirates experienced rapid growth by continuously expanding its route network and investing in modern aircraft. Its location in Dubai positioned the airline as a major global hub, allowing seamless connections between Europe, Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

Today, Emirates is widely recognized for its extensive long-haul operations and premium onboard experience, delivering high levels of comfort in every cabin class. The airline operates the world’s largest widebody fleet, featuring Airbus A380s and Boeing 777s, which support efficient operations on high-demand international routes.

Headquarters And Hub

Emirates’ main hub is Dubai International Airport (DXB), one of the busiest and most modern airports in the world. Strategically located between Europe, Asia, and Africa, Dubai serves as an ideal connecting point for travelers from around the globe. Its geographic position allows Emirates to operate efficiently across long-haul routes while providing convenient connections between multiple continents, helping the airline maintain its reputation as a leading international carrier.

The airport features state-of-the-art facilities and terminals, designed to handle millions of passengers annually with ease and comfort. From advanced baggage handling systems to modern lounges and spacious boarding gates, Dubai International Airport combines efficiency with luxury. Emirates has leveraged these facilities to enhance its operations, ensuring smooth transfers for connecting passengers and maintaining a high standard of service across all classes.

Dubai International Airport has played a central role in Emirates’ rapid growth and global expansion. By using Dubai as its hub, the airline can efficiently link high-demand destinations, expand its international network, and optimize flight schedules. This strategic hub has not only enabled Emirates to dominate long-haul travel but also helped Dubai establish itself as a global aviation center, attracting travelers, businesses, and tourism from every corner of the world.

Fleet Overview

Emirates currently operates the world’s largest widebody fleet, dominated by the Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 families. The airline has a total of 118 Airbus A380-800 aircraft, with 97 active and 21 inactive, reflecting the continued importance of the type on high-demand, long-haul routes. The A380 remains central to Emirates’ network strategy, particularly on trunk routes where high capacity and premium offerings are essential.

Alongside the A380, Emirates is gradually introducing the Airbus A350-900 as part of its long-term fleet evolution. At present, 14 A350-900s are active, with a significant 59 aircraft still to be delivered. This order book highlights the airline’s shift toward newer-generation aircraft that provide improved fuel efficiency, lower emissions, and greater flexibility compared to older widebody types.

The Boeing 777 continues to form the backbone of Emirates’ operations, especially the Boeing 777-300ER variant. The airline operates a total of 119 777-300ERs, with 116 currently active, supporting its extensive global long-haul network. In addition, Emirates maintains a strong cargo presence with 11 active Boeing 777-200F freighters and 10 more on order, reinforcing its role in global air freight. All fleet figures cited above are based on data from ch-aviation.

Global Network

The airline operates flights to more than 130 cities across six continents, making it one of the most globally connected carriers in the world. This extensive network allows passengers to reach major international hubs, business centers, and popular leisure destinations with ease. Whether traveling for work, family, or vacation, passengers benefit from convenient access to an extraordinary range of destinations, from bustling metropolitan cities to remote holiday spots. By continually expanding its route network, the airline ensures it remains at the forefront of global connectivity.

From Dubai, the airline operates thousands of weekly flights, providing passengers with high-frequency service and flexible scheduling options. Its hub in Dubai serves as a central gateway connecting the East and West, enabling travelers to move seamlessly between continents. The airline’s operational strategy emphasizes efficiency, comfort, and convenience, with modern aircraft and state-of-the-art facilities designed to enhance the travel experience. This robust flight schedule supports both short-haul and long-haul journeys, meeting the needs of a diverse passenger base.

With a strong presence in Europe, the Americas, Asia, Africa, and Oceania, the airline prioritizes high-demand international routes, particularly long-haul connections that link major global markets. By focusing on these strategic routes, it maximizes passenger access while maintaining a competitive edge in the global aviation industry. This approach also allows the airline to provide premium services, extensive in-flight options, and tailored travel experiences for frequent flyers, business travelers, and tourists alike. Its commitment to quality, reliability, and connectivity has cemented its reputation as a leading international carrier, trusted by millions of passengers worldwide.

Passenger Experience And Cabins

The airline offers a range of travel classes designed to meet the needs of all passengers, including economy, business, and first class, with premium economy. Each cabin is thoughtfully designed to provide comfort, convenience, and a superior travel experience, ensuring that every journey meets the expectations of leisure and business travelers alike. Whether passengers are looking for affordable travel, extra space and amenities, or the ultimate in luxury, the airline provides options tailored to every preference.

Passengers can enjoy award-winning in-flight entertainment through the airline’s ICE system, offering an extensive selection of movies, TV shows, music, games, and more. The entertainment platform is regularly updated to ensure a fresh and engaging experience for travelers of all ages, making even the longest flights enjoyable and relaxing. This commitment to in-flight entertainment has earned the airline numerous accolades and is a key part of its reputation for excellence in passenger experience.

Onboard, the airline offers a range of luxury features designed to enhance the travel experience across all cabins. First class on the Airbus A380 features private suites with personal showers, while business class offers lie-flat seats and advanced comfort amenities for a restful long-haul experience. High-quality catering and attentive service are delivered across all cabins, ensuring that passengers enjoy gourmet meals, fine beverages, and personalized care throughout their journey. These features, combined with meticulous attention to detail, create a travel experience that is both comfortable and memorable, reinforcing the airline’s position as a leader in premium international aviation.

Innovation And Future Plans

The airline’s fleet modernization strategy centers on introducing next-generation aircraft such as the Boeing 777X and the Airbus A350. On order are 35 Boeing 777-8s and a substantial 235 Boeing 777-9s, forming the core of the future long-haul fleet, alongside 59 Airbus A350-900s scheduled for delivery. In addition, the airline has ordered 30 Boeing 787 Dreamliners, split evenly between 15 787-10s and 15 787-8s, adding further flexibility and efficiency. These aircraft offer significantly improved fuel efficiency, longer range, and enhanced passenger comfort, allowing the airline to progressively replace older widebody jets while improving operational reliability.

A key part of the passenger experience upgrade is the implementation of Starlink high-speed satellite internet across the Airbus A380 and Boeing 777 fleets. This technology enables faster and more reliable connectivity at cruising altitude, supporting streaming, messaging, and productivity throughout the flight. When combined with new-generation aircraft deliveries and updated cabin products, this initiative reflects a broader effort to deliver a consistently modern and connected onboard experience.

Sustainability remains a central pillar of the airline’s long-term strategy, particularly in reducing emissions on long-haul operations. The introduction of aircraft such as the 777X, A350, and 787, each designed with lower fuel burn and reduced emissions, supports these goals, alongside operational efficiencies and the use of sustainable aviation fuel. Expansion plans to new global destinations will be closely tied to these efficiencies, enabling network growth while maintaining a strong focus on environmental responsibility.

title: Aemetis, XCF, and the Invisible Value Shift That Will Define Renewables in 2026 - Biofuels Digest
description:
The It Girl: Aemetis Biogas If “It” is that intangible quality that takes something merely promising and makes it irresistible, Aemetis has it in spades.
Their subsidiary Aemetis Biogas LLC has just received funds from the sale of $17 million of federal clean energy tax credits — including Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credits and Section 48 Investment Tax Credits.
The Oomph Girl: XCF Global If oomph is the quality that makes investors reach for their checkbook before the set is even built — XCF Global has it.
And they’re doing it with a narrative investors already adore: nuclear = energy security + industry revival + jobs + big-ticket growth.
Mike Hewitt, Chief Executive Officer of IP3, added: “Clean, reliable nuclear power is increasingly being pursued as foundational infrastructure for American energy security and industrial growth.
text:
Hollywood figured this out a century ago. They don’t sell celluloid — they sell star power. If you have an established icon like Clara Bow, you sell It: allure, magnetism, and the special sparkle that turns a performer into a phenomenon. If you have a rising force like Ann Sheridan, you sell Oomph: that impossible-to-bottle mystique and sex appeal that storms the box office before the critics even learn her name.

It and Oomph. That’s the formula.

For renewable fuels, that moment arrives in 2026. The gallons of green liquid? Not the star anymore. The real value lies in the attributes — the verified, tradeable, financeable proof of carbon benefit.

Like:

• Energy Attribute Certificates (RECs, Guarantees of Origin)

• Zero-Emission Credits (rewarding firm, carbon-free generation)

• Low-Carbon Fuel Synthesis Attributes (SAFc and friends)

And when you look at eSAF, the ultimate Oomph emerges: small modular nuclear reactors paired with hydrogen and fuel synthesis — precision-engineered to electrify Wall Street. And this isn’t theory — the deals are already in the news.

The It Girl: Aemetis Biogas

If “It” is that intangible quality that takes something merely promising and makes it irresistible, Aemetis has it in spades.

Their subsidiary Aemetis Biogas LLC has just received funds from the sale of $17 million of federal clean energy tax credits — including Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credits and Section 48 Investment Tax Credits. This wasn’t a paper shuffle — it delivered $15 million in net cash into the business, after transaction costs. Breakdown:

~$12M from Section 48 ITC tied to constructing a dairy digester that’s already producing biogas

~$5M from Section 45Z PTC tied to renewable natural gas production during 2025

And that’s just the first act. Aemetis expects:

Significantly higher 45Z credit values as volumes scale and guidance strengthens

An additional $10.5 million Section 45C credit in 2026 (already IRS + DOE approved)

That is It Factor economics: proven molecules + proven metadata = proven money. This isn’t Hollywood hype. It’s recurring cash flow with receipts.

The Oomph Girl: XCF Global

If oomph is the quality that makes investors reach for their checkbook before the set is even built — XCF Global has it. They’ve announced a sweeping non-binding MOU with IP3, Southern Energy Renewables, and DevvStream to explore an integrated model for:

SMR nuclear power

Electro-sustainable aviation fuel

Tokenized, verifiable environmental attributes

This is how high-value compliance markets get fed — continuously, reliably, and at industrial scale. The collaboration envisions:

SMR-generated electricity powering both electrolysis + fuel synthesis

Excess zero-carbon power supporting booming AI/data-center customers

Digital MRV + provenance tracking ensuring every claim checks out

“Book-and-claim” SAF structures enabling climate benefits to fly globally even before fuel does

This isn’t yesterday’s offset story. This is data-driven decarbonization that Wall Street can underwrite. And they’re doing it with a narrative investors already adore: nuclear = energy security + industry revival + jobs + big-ticket growth. Nothing has more Oomph right now.

They Said It

“This tax credit sale represents an important step in monetizing federal clean fuel transferable tax incentives and establishing a new recurring source of cash flow,” said Eric McAfee, Chairman and CEO of Aemetis. “This is our first sale of a Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit from dairy RNG, and we expect additional Section 45Z transactions in 2026 and future years from ongoing renewable natural gas production, along with additional Section 48 transactions from ongoing digester construction. With the completion of $95 million of ITC transactions and today’s first Section 45Z sale, we are executing our tax credit monetization strategy. We expect federal 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credits to be a rapidly growing source of operating cash flow to support the expansion of production and new job creation.”

Chris Cooper, Chief Executive Officer of XCF Global, commented: “This MOU reflects XCF’s disciplined approach to evaluating infrastructure and partnerships that can strengthen the scalability, reliability, and carbon performance of next-generation sustainable aviation fuels. Firm, zero-carbon power is an important enabler for eSAF pathways, and this collaboration allows us to assess how integrated power, fuel, and environmental-attribute frameworks could support broader adoption of clean fuels.”

RDML (Ret.) Mike Hewitt, Chief Executive Officer of IP3, added: “Clean, reliable nuclear power is increasingly being pursued as foundational infrastructure for American energy security and industrial growth. We are excited to explore a strategic relationship with XCF, DevvStream, and Southern, including the potential deployment of small modular reactor technology to provide firm power and support e‑SAF production for European markets. IP3’s business model to develop infrastructure projects to privatize Small Modular Reactors for multiple offtakers such as AI and data centers that support government and commercial requirements. We believe pairing firm power development with practical environmental‑asset design and monetization can create a differentiated platform that meets real customer demand while delivering the transparency the market expects.”

Sunny Trinh, Chief Executive Officer of DevvStream, commented:“Together, we are exploring real-world asset and tokenized environmental-asset frameworks with the potential to unlock additional value, improve liquidity, and help lower the delivered cost of clean energy and fuels. We see this as a potential America-first model that combines U.S. resources, digital infrastructure, and scalable markets.”

Jay Patel, Chief Executive Officer of Southern Energy, added: “This MOU reflects our focus on putting American energy, infrastructure, and production first. As the development of advanced nuclear platforms gains momentum, we believe the goal of developing and deploying firm, domestic power is becoming essential for fuels, manufacturing, and data-driven industries. We are committed to exploring how nuclear power, combined with U.S. biomass resources, can enable an integrated, multi-product approach that strengthens U.S. industrial leadership while remaining globally competitive.”

Oomph Wins the Audition. Persistence Wins the Franchise.

Look — right now, the financial markets care less about feasible and more about financeable. Investors want:

bankable revenue streams

compliance premiums

physical + digital verification

infrastructure that already exists or can be reused

Which is why Aemetis’ bolt-on model might be the most powerful story of all: Oomph gets you noticed. Persistence gets you greenlit.

Nuclear may be the red-hot starlet of the energy world — stealing headlines and dazzling regulators — but the projects that endure are the ones already delivering today.

The lesson of 2026? The molecule is the movie. The It is the attribute. And only the persistent get a sequel.

title: Fiji Airways Warns of New Potential Disruptions on the Funafuti and Nadi-Vava'u Flights ...
description:
Fiji Airways Warns of New Potential Disruptions on the Funafuti and Nadi-Vava’u Flights Due to Fuel Shortages, Passengers May Experience Baggage Offloading Fiji Airways has issued a travel alert for two of its routes in the region, warning customers of the possibility of disruption owing to fuel shortages at the airports of destinations in these islands.
Impact on Passengers and Luggage Fiji Airways has advised that due to weight limitations, both passengers and their checked baggage may be offloaded from flights where necessary.
Airline’s Efforts to Address the Fuel Shortage Fiji Airways has emphasized that the fuel shortage is temporary, with fuel supplies expected to be restored by mid-January for Funafuti and by January 9, 2026 for Nadi–Vava’u.
Future Focus: Improving Sustainability and Regional Connectivity Looking toward the future, Fiji Airways is likely to focus on further optimizing fuel management and enhancing regional connectivity.
In the meantime, Fiji Airways continues to have a service support mechanism for travelers during the transition period.
text:
Fiji Airways Warns of New Potential Disruptions on the Funafuti and Nadi-Vava’u Flights Due to Fuel Shortages, Passengers May Experience Baggage Offloading

Fiji Airways has issued a travel alert for two of its routes in the region, warning customers of the possibility of disruption owing to fuel shortages at the airports of destinations in these islands. The air operator, however, has confirmed the operation of flights on the routes Funafuti and Nadi-Vava’u, but there will be constraints owing to fuel shortages at the airports involved.

The flights to Funafuti will operate under restrictions until January 15, 2026, according to the airline, as the plane will have to take more contingency fuel from Fiji. The impact of the additional weight of the fuel will result in the plane carrying reduced capacity, and the flights will not operate at their normal capacity. This will result in the possibility of carrying out passenger and cargo offloads to enhance the weight and balance of the plane. The same will be the scenario for the flights operating on the Nadi-Vava’u route, as there will be a scarcity of fuel until January 9, 2026.

Impact on Passengers and Luggage

Fiji Airways has advised that due to weight limitations, both passengers and their checked baggage may be offloaded from flights where necessary. Affected passengers and luggage will be accommodated on the next available service, subject to operational availability.

To manage the situation, passengers are being urged to carry essential items and overnight necessities in their hand luggage, ensuring that it falls within standard carry-on rules. This recommendation is designed to minimize inconvenience and ensure passengers have what they need during their travels.

Airline’s Efforts to Address the Fuel Shortage

Fiji Airways has emphasized that the fuel shortage is temporary, with fuel supplies expected to be restored by mid-January for Funafuti and by January 9, 2026 for Nadi–Vava’u. While these disruptions are inconvenient, the airline is working to ensure that passengers can continue their journeys with minimal delays.

Future Travel Impacts: Long-Term Effects on Regional Operations

While the current disruptions will be short-term, Fiji Airways’s ongoing adjustments to its fuel strategy and capacity planning are likely to have longer-term impacts on the airline’s regional operations. The airline’s reliance on contingency fuel from Fiji and the limited weight capacity of aircraft can affect flight schedules, especially on high-demand routes like Funafuti and Nadi–Vava’u. As the airline prepares for an increase in international travel demand, particularly for leisure tourism in the Pacific region, these fuel-related disruptions may prompt future improvements to regional flight scheduling and fuel distribution strategies to ensure consistent service delivery.

Fiji Airways’ efforts to return to normal flight operations after fuel supplies are restored will likely provide valuable insights into regional aviation dynamics and how to better manage fuel-related challenges in the future. As international tourism rebounds across the Pacific, maintaining efficient, sustainable flight operations will be critical for the airline to meet growing demand, especially from international travelers seeking tropical destinations.

Future Focus: Improving Sustainability and Regional Connectivity

Looking toward the future, Fiji Airways is likely to focus on further optimizing fuel management and enhancing regional connectivity. This may include exploring sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) options and innovative fuel solutions that could prevent similar issues in the long term. With a growing number of tourists heading to Pacific island nations, it will be essential for Fiji Airways to ensure reliable service while reducing its environmental impact.

Additionally, expanding partnerships with local airports and governments to streamline fuel supply chains and increase airlift capacity in remote destinations like Funafuti and Nadi–Vava’u will be key to minimizing operational challenges in the coming years. This will also support tourism growth by making travel to these regions more accessible and efficient.

Managing Short-Term Disruptions for Long-Term Growth

The recent fuel shortages and associated flight restrictions within the Funafuti and Nadi – Vava’u routes are only temporary; however, they underscore the value of long-term planning in terms of fuel management and Pacific connectivity strategies for Fiji Airways. This aviation company will continue to develop approaches in order to optimize future performance in light of increasing demand in the Pacific tourism industry.

In the meantime, Fiji Airways continues to have a service support mechanism for travelers during the transition period. With a focus on sustainability, regional expansion, and managing fuel costs, the company is well-positioned to take the tourism sector in the Pacific and other regions to greater heights in the coming years.

title: Emirates Extends Lead As Top Global Airline - Menafn.com
description:
(MENAFN- The Arabian Post) Arabian Post Staff -Dubai Emirates strengthened its standing in 2025 as the world's largest international airline, carrying 55.6 million passengers across almost 180,580 flights and reinforcing Dubai's role as a central hub for long-haul air travel.
The airline also placed orders for 73 new aircraft, signalling confidence in sustained long-term growth and in the resilience of global travel demand.
The airline's expanding global footprint in 2025 was framed by a milestone anniversary, with Emirates marking four decades since the launch of its operations in October.
Emirates has increasingly leaned on data-driven planning to optimise turnaround times at Dubai International Airport, one of the world's busiest for international passengers.
Passenger throughput through Dubai International Airport feeds into hospitality, retail and logistics, reinforcing the city's positioning as a global crossroads.
text:
(MENAFN- The Arabian Post) Arabian Post Staff -Dubai

Emirates strengthened its standing in 2025 as the world's largest international airline, carrying 55.6 million passengers across almost 180,580 flights and reinforcing Dubai's role as a central hub for long-haul air travel. The carrier said the scale of its operations during the year equated to circling the Earth more than 29,000 times, underlining the breadth of its global network at a time when international aviation demand continued to normalise after years of disruption.

The airline also placed orders for 73 new aircraft, signalling confidence in sustained long-term growth and in the resilience of global travel demand. Fleet expansion remains a central pillar of Emirates' strategy, aimed at maintaining capacity on high-traffic routes while opening or strengthening links to emerging markets across Asia, Africa and the Americas. Industry analysts view the order book as one of the most closely watched indicators of the carrier's outlook, given its dependence on wide-body aircraft and ultra-long-haul connectivity.

The airline's expanding global footprint in 2025 was framed by a milestone anniversary, with Emirates marking four decades since the launch of its operations in October. In a statement issued on Wednesday, the airline said the year reflected a“clear vision for shaping the future of travel through sustained excellence”, pointing to operational consistency, service standards and network breadth as defining features of its performance.

Passenger numbers remained below pre-pandemic peaks on certain routes due to aircraft delivery delays affecting the wider aviation sector, yet load factors were described by industry data providers as robust across most regions. Demand on Europe-Asia and Middle East-Americas corridors continued to anchor traffic flows, while routes to South Asia and parts of Africa saw steady growth, driven by both leisure and labour mobility.

See also Mubadala Capital eyes tokenised private-market access via KAIO

Operationally, Emirates' near-180,000 flights highlighted the scale at which the airline manages complex scheduling and logistics. Aviation specialists note that maintaining punctuality and service quality across such volumes requires heavy investment in crew training, digital systems and ground operations. Emirates has increasingly leaned on data-driven planning to optimise turnaround times at Dubai International Airport, one of the world's busiest for international passengers.

The aircraft order announced during the year included a mix of next-generation wide-body jets intended to replace older models and support future expansion. These aircraft are expected to deliver improved fuel efficiency and lower emissions per seat, a key consideration as regulators and investors place greater scrutiny on aviation's environmental footprint. While long-haul flying remains carbon-intensive, Emirates has signalled incremental steps towards sustainability, including operational efficiencies and participation in sustainable aviation fuel initiatives, though large-scale adoption remains constrained by supply and cost.

Competition among global network carriers intensified during 2025, with rivals in Europe, North America and Asia restoring capacity and adding frequencies on overlapping routes. Despite this, Emirates retained its edge in international passenger volumes, largely due to its hub-and-spoke model centred on Dubai, which allows the airline to aggregate demand from multiple regions and deploy high-capacity aircraft efficiently. Analysts say this structure continues to give Emirates flexibility that point-to-point operators struggle to replicate on intercontinental routes.

The airline's performance also had broader implications for Dubai's economy. Aviation remains a cornerstone of the emirate's tourism, trade and services sectors, supporting thousands of jobs directly and indirectly. Passenger throughput through Dubai International Airport feeds into hospitality, retail and logistics, reinforcing the city's positioning as a global crossroads. Government data have consistently linked airline capacity growth with higher visitor numbers and stronger non-oil economic activity.

See also Mubadala charts deeper Asia investment push

Internally, Emirates focused on workforce stability after years of volatility across the aviation labour market. Recruitment and training programmes were expanded to ensure sufficient pilots, cabin crew and engineers to support the enlarged schedule. Industry observers note that staff availability has become as critical as aircraft supply in determining how quickly airlines can scale operations.

Also published on Medium.

Notice an issue? Arabian Post strives to deliver the most accurate and reliable information to its readers. If you believe you have identified an error or inconsistency in this article, please don't hesitate to contact our editorial team at editor[at]thearabianpost[dot]com. We are committed to promptly addressing any concerns and ensuring the highest level of journalistic integrity.

title: Russia's New Mi-34M1 Helicopter Makes First Flight with Indigenous Power - Jetline Marvel
authors: Sana khan, Jetline Marvel Aviation News
description:
The maiden flight marks an important milestone in restoring a segment long dominated by foreign light helicopters.
Mi-34M1 Enters Flight Testing Phase The Mi-34M1 completed its first test flight lasting around ten minutes, during which engineers evaluated the helicopter’s stability, controllability, and structural loads.
Powered by the New VK-650V Engine At the heart of the Mi-34M1 is the VK-650V turboshaft engine, developed by the United Engine Corporation under Rostec.
Replacing Foreign Light Helicopters One of the Mi-34M1’s most strategic roles is filling a market niche previously dominated by foreign light helicopters.
Conclusion With the Mi-34M1 entering flight tests, Russia is reasserting itself in the light helicopter segment.
text:
At a time when sanctions and supply chain restrictions are reshaping the global aerospace industry, Russia is pushing forward with a clear message: domestic aviation is not slowing down.

Rostec’s “Russian Helicopters” holding has officially begun flight tests of the Mi-34M1, a modern light single-engine multipurpose helicopter designed entirely around Russian-made technologies. The maiden flight marks an important milestone in restoring a segment long dominated by foreign light helicopters.

Mi-34M1 Enters Flight Testing Phase

The Mi-34M1 completed its first test flight lasting around ten minutes, during which engineers evaluated the helicopter’s stability, controllability, and structural loads. The aircraft performed standard horizontal flight maneuvers and turns, allowing specialists to assess how key systems behave under real aerodynamic stress.

According to Rostec, the helicopter demonstrated predictable handling and strong maneuverability—two qualities essential for training, monitoring, and civilian operations. The test campaign confirms that the Mi-34M1 is progressing steadily toward certification.

Powered by the New VK-650V Engine

At the heart of the Mi-34M1 is the VK-650V turboshaft engine, developed by the United Engine Corporation under Rostec. This engine represents a major achievement, as it is the first Russian-designed powerplant for light helicopters in the up-to-four-ton takeoff weight category.

Delivering 650 horsepower at takeoff, the VK-650V is built around a modular architecture that simplifies maintenance and extends service life. It is also equipped with a digital full-authority engine control (FADEC) system, improving fuel efficiency, reliability, and pilot workload management—especially important for training and private aviation.

Key Specifications (Preliminary)

While certification testing is still underway, the Mi-34M1 is expected to feature the following performance characteristics:

Engine: VK-650V turboshaft (650 hp)

Maximum speed: ~240 km/h

Cruise speed: ~210 km/h

Operational range: ~500 km

Payload capacity: ~600 kg (internal and external combined)

Crew: 1–2 pilots

Passenger capacity: Up to 3–4 passengers

Takeoff weight class: Up to 4 tons

These parameters place the Mi-34M1 firmly in the same operational category as popular Western light helicopters, while offering lower dependency on foreign components.

Designed for Versatility and Ease of Operation

Rostec CEO Sergey Chemezov emphasized that the Mi-34M1 was developed with simplicity and versatility in mind. The helicopter is highly maneuverable, easy to fly, and economical to maintain—qualities that make it suitable for a wide range of missions.

Primary roles include:

Passenger and private transport

Aerial monitoring and patrol missions

Flight training and pilot instruction

Aviation sports and aerobatic flying

Its straightforward maintenance philosophy also makes it attractive for regional operators, flying clubs, and private owners.

Replacing Foreign Light Helicopters

One of the Mi-34M1’s most strategic roles is filling a market niche previously dominated by foreign light helicopters. Due to rising operating costs, spare parts shortages, and unofficial maintenance practices, many imported helicopters have become expensive and difficult to support.

The Mi-34M1 offers a domestically supported alternative, with local manufacturing, certified maintenance chains, and predictable operating costs—an increasingly important factor for Russian civil aviation.Mi-34M1 proves that modern, competitive aircraft can be developed using entirely domestic technologies, from engines to onboard avionics.

Conclusion

With the Mi-34M1 entering flight tests, Russia is reasserting itself in the light helicopter segment. Combining modern onboard systems, the new VK-650V engine, and a focus on ease of operation, the helicopter is positioned as a practical, homegrown solution for civilian aviation, training, and private use.

As testing continues, the Mi-34M1 could soon become a familiar sight in Russian skies—quietly replacing foreign machines with a domestically built alternative.

title: Delta Air Lines: The Value Play in a Sky-High Market for 2026 - FinancialContent
description:
Delta Air Lines (NYSE: DAL) has emerged at the forefront of this search.
By the end of 2025, Delta successfully slashed its adjusted net debt from over $21 billion to approximately $15.3 billion, reclaiming its investment-grade status across all major credit agencies.
Winners and Losers in the New Aviation Landscape In the competitive landscape of early 2026, Delta’s "premium-first" strategy has created a widening moat between it and its peers.
The Road Ahead: Buybacks and Dividends Looking toward the remainder of 2026, the market is anticipating a strategic pivot in Delta’s capital allocation.
Final Assessment for the 2026 Investor As we move into 2026, Delta Air Lines stands as a testament to the power of disciplined financial management and brand positioning.
text:
As the global financial markets ring in 2026, a stark divergence has emerged between the high-flying valuations of the broader indices and the grounded, cash-generating reality of the industrial sector. With the S&P 500 trading at a historically steep forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 23x, driven by a multi-year surge in technology and artificial intelligence, investors are increasingly scouring the market for "quality value"—companies with fortress balance sheets, dominant market positions, and valuations that have yet to catch up to their fundamental earnings power.

Delta Air Lines (NYSE: DAL) has emerged at the forefront of this search. While the broader market appears priced for perfection, Delta enters 2026 trading at a modest 9.5x forward earnings, despite coming off a fiscal 2025 that saw record-breaking revenue and a massive reduction in long-term debt. This valuation gap represents one of the most significant opportunities in the large-cap space, positioning the Atlanta-based carrier as a top pick for value-oriented portfolios in the coming year.

The Crusade Against Debt and the Premium Pivot

The story of Delta’s ascent to a top value pick for 2026 began in earnest during its "crusade against debt" throughout 2024 and 2025. Following the turbulence of the early 2020s, Delta’s management team, led by CEO Ed Bastian, executed a disciplined capital allocation strategy that prioritized balance sheet repair over aggressive capacity expansion. By the end of 2025, Delta successfully slashed its adjusted net debt from over $21 billion to approximately $15.3 billion, reclaiming its investment-grade status across all major credit agencies. This deleveraging has not only lowered interest expenses but has also cleared the runway for increased shareholder returns in 2026.

Central to this financial transformation has been Delta’s strategic pivot toward "premiumization." Throughout 2025, the airline saw a structural shift in consumer behavior, where high-income travelers increasingly opted for premium cabins, including Delta One and Premium Select. This shift was underscored by the record-breaking performance of Delta’s partnership with American Express (NYSE: AXP), which generated over $7 billion in high-margin remuneration in 2025 alone. By focusing on the high-end consumer, Delta has successfully insulated itself from the price wars that have traditionally plagued the lower-cost segments of the industry.

Winners and Losers in the New Aviation Landscape

In the competitive landscape of early 2026, Delta’s "premium-first" strategy has created a widening moat between it and its peers. United Airlines Holdings (NASDAQ: UAL) has remained a formidable competitor, also benefiting from international expansion and premium demand, but it continues to carry a heavier debt load than Delta. Meanwhile, American Airlines Group (NASDAQ: AAL) has struggled to achieve the same level of margin expansion, as it grapples with higher operational complexities and a slower path to deleveraging.

The real losers in this environment have been the traditional low-cost carriers. Southwest Airlines (NYSE: LUV), long the darling of the budget sector, spent much of 2025 undergoing a radical transformation—including the introduction of assigned seating and premium cabin options—in a desperate bid to capture the high-yield travelers that Delta has already secured. As fuel prices and labor costs remained elevated through 2025, the thin margins of the "no-frills" model became increasingly unsustainable, forcing a consolidation of the market that has ultimately benefited Delta’s pricing power.

Resilience Amidst Industry Constraints

The wider significance of Delta’s current position lies in its ability to thrive despite persistent industry-wide supply constraints. As of January 1, 2026, the aviation industry continues to be hamstrung by aircraft delivery delays from both Boeing (NYSE: BA) and Airbus (OTC:EADSY). While these delays have limited the industry’s ability to add new seats, they have inadvertently acted as a floor for ticket prices. Delta’s older but well-maintained fleet and its superior operational reliability have allowed it to maintain record load factors—projected at 84% for 2026—while competitors struggle with grounded planes and maintenance backlogs.

Furthermore, a significant tailwind for the airline sector in 2026 is the cooling of global energy prices. Brent crude is forecast to average $58 per barrel this year, down from $66 in 2025. For an airline of Delta’s scale, this reduction in its largest variable cost represents a massive boost to the bottom line. When combined with the "premiumization" trend, Delta is entering 2026 with a rare combination of falling costs and rising yields, a scenario that historically precedes significant stock price appreciation.

The Road Ahead: Buybacks and Dividends

Looking toward the remainder of 2026, the market is anticipating a strategic pivot in Delta’s capital allocation. With the debt-to-EBITDAR ratio now sitting comfortably at 2.0x, analysts expect the company to transition from debt repayment to aggressive shareholder returns. Short-term possibilities include a significant hike in the quarterly dividend and the potential announcement of a multi-billion dollar share buyback program, which would be the first major repurchase since the pre-pandemic era.

However, challenges remain. The industry must still navigate a complex regulatory environment and the ongoing pressure to invest in sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). Delta’s ability to integrate these environmental costs without eroding its 11.5% operating margin will be a key metric for investors to watch. Additionally, while the "K-shaped" economy has favored Delta’s premium focus, any broader slowdown in high-end consumer spending could test the resilience of its 2026 earnings guidance.

Final Assessment for the 2026 Investor

As we move into 2026, Delta Air Lines stands as a testament to the power of disciplined financial management and brand positioning. In a market where many stocks are trading at valuations that assume decades of uninterrupted growth, Delta offers a "margin of safety" that is increasingly rare. With a consensus analyst price target of $82—representing a nearly 20% upside from current levels—the stock is priced as a cyclical airline but is performing like a high-quality industrial powerhouse.

For investors, the key takeaways are clear: Delta has fixed its balance sheet, captured the most profitable segment of the travel market, and is now poised to benefit from lower fuel costs and restricted supply. While the tech sector may continue to capture headlines, the real value in 2026 is likely to be found in the blue skies of the aviation sector. Investors should keep a close eye on quarterly earnings reports for confirmation of the promised buybacks, which could serve as the final catalyst to close the valuation gap between Delta and the broader market.

This content is intended for informational purposes only and is not financial advice.

title: Advanced Biofuels Canada Association Welcomes Federal Biofuels Production Incentive ...
description:
VANCOUVER, CANADA, January 1, 2026 /EINPresswire.com/ -- "The Biofuels Production Incentive takes effect today, providing immediate support to protect Canadian biofuel production capacity and strengthen Canada’s energy security,” said Fred Ghatala, President of Advanced Biofuels Canada Association.
“The Biofuels Production Incentive supports Canadian jobs, Canadian feedstocks, and Canadian fuel supply, helping keep clean fuel investment and production anchored in Canada amid ongoing trade and policy uncertainty.
“While the Biofuels Production Incentive is a positive short-term measure for 2026 and 2027, it does not fully close the gap with U.S. production subsidies.
Long-term competitiveness will require complementary, structural measures that provide certainty for investment in Canadian renewable fuel production and feedstock supply chains.
“Advanced Biofuels Canada Association encourages provinces and territories to engage actively at the federal-provincial-territorial table to deliver durable, long-term investment-ready solutions.
text:
VANCOUVER, CANADA, January 1, 2026 /EINPresswire.com/ -- "The Biofuels Production Incentive takes effect today, providing immediate support to protect Canadian biofuel production capacity and strengthen Canada’s energy security,” said Fred Ghatala, President of Advanced Biofuels Canada Association.

“The Biofuels Production Incentive was announced by Prime Minister Carney on September 5, 2025, and today marks the shift from policy intent to delivery.

“Canadian producers have been operating at a competitive disadvantage since the introduction of the United States’ Inflation Reduction Act and the Clean Fuel Production Credit, which significantly lowered U.S. production costs and reshaped North American capital flows.

“The Biofuels Production Incentive supports Canadian jobs, Canadian feedstocks, and Canadian fuel supply, helping keep clean fuel investment and production anchored in Canada amid ongoing trade and policy uncertainty. Biofuels are an immediately deployable solution that reduces emissions while supporting rural economies, well-paying jobs, domestic feedstocks like canola, and greater energy security.

“Advanced Biofuels Canada Association represents producers of biodiesel, ethanol, renewable diesel, renewable gasoline, and sustainable aviation fuel, which are blended into the transportation fuels Canadians rely on every day.

“While the Biofuels Production Incentive is a positive short-term measure for 2026 and 2027, it does not fully close the gap with U.S. production subsidies. Long-term competitiveness will require complementary, structural measures that provide certainty for investment in Canadian renewable fuel production and feedstock supply chains.

“The federal–provincial–territorial table on low-carbon fuels is already established, and it is the next critical step to align long-term policies that keep Canadian biofuel production stable, thriving, and anchored in Canada, rather than leaving Canada’s supply and competitiveness exposed to foreign policy decisions.

“Provinces have a central role to play in ensuring Canada remains attractive for capital investments in biofuel production, feedstock processing, and renewable fuel infrastructure, while ensuring that farmers and rural communities capture the long-term jobs, revenues, and value-added benefits these supply chains generate.

“Advanced Biofuels Canada Association encourages provinces and territories to engage actively at the federal-provincial-territorial table to deliver durable, long-term investment-ready solutions. Coordinated policy action will protect existing facilities, attract new capital, and keep biofuel investment and production in Canada.

“Today’s implementation is important groundwork, and the focus now must be on durable policy frameworks that allow the sector to grow.”

Advanced Biofuels Canada is the national industry voice for producers, distributors, and technology providers of non-fossil, low carbon, and sustainable fuel replacements to gasoline, diesel, jet, and marine fuels. Our members operate over 45 billion litres of low carbon fuel production capacity globally and are significant suppliers to renewable and low carbon fuel in Canada and worldwide. For more information, visit www.advancedbiofuels.ca.

title: The Production Paradox: Why Global Commodities Are Flooding the Market as Prices Crater in 2026
description:
As the world rings in 2026, the global commodity markets are locked in a baffling contradiction.
This "Production Paradox" is reshaping the global economy, as major producers choose to defend market share and leverage low-cost efficiencies rather than curb supply to support prices.
Throughout 2025, the World Bank and IMF recorded a 7% annual decline in commodity prices, a trend that is forecasted to repeat in 2026.
Winners and Losers in the Low-Cost Era In this environment, the clear winners are the "low-cost leaders" who can remain profitable even at depressed price levels.
Summary and Investor Takeaways The global commodity market of 2026 is defined by a fierce battle for dominance in a low-margin world.
text:
As the world rings in 2026, the global commodity markets are locked in a baffling contradiction. Despite a four-year downward trend that has pushed the broad commodity index to six-year lows, production levels for everything from crude oil to battery metals are reaching historic highs. This "Production Paradox" is reshaping the global economy, as major producers choose to defend market share and leverage low-cost efficiencies rather than curb supply to support prices.

The immediate implications are a boon for consumers and manufacturers, who are enjoying the lowest input costs since the pre-pandemic era. However, for the commodity giants and the nations that depend on them, the environment has become a brutal "survival of the fittest." With Brent crude hovering near $60 per barrel and agricultural surpluses mounting, the market is bracing for a year where volume is the only shield against vanishing margins.

The Race to the Bottom: A Timeline of the 2026 Glut

The current state of oversupply did not happen overnight. It is the culmination of a multi-year investment cycle that began in 2022 and 2023, when record-high prices incentivized massive capital expenditures in new extraction technologies and expanded acreage. By late 2024, these projects began coming online just as global demand—particularly from a slowing Chinese industrial sector—started to cool. Throughout 2025, the World Bank and IMF recorded a 7% annual decline in commodity prices, a trend that is forecasted to repeat in 2026.

Key players in this drama include the OPEC+ alliance, which has struggled to maintain production discipline in the face of surging output from non-member nations. The United States and Guyana have emerged as the primary disruptors in the energy sector, with the U.S. Permian Basin reaching unprecedented efficiency levels. Meanwhile, in the metals sector, Indonesia and China have aggressively expanded nickel and lithium processing capacities, deliberately maintaining high output to crash prices and drive higher-cost Western competitors out of the market. This "Strategic Market Share Defense" has left the market in a state of bearish stability, where supply remains stubbornly high despite the lack of a price floor.

Winners and Losers in the Low-Cost Era

In this environment, the clear winners are the "low-cost leaders" who can remain profitable even at depressed price levels. ExxonMobil (NYSE: XOM) stands at the forefront of this group. By leveraging its acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources and its advantaged assets in Guyana, ExxonMobil has lowered its breakeven costs to near $30 per barrel. While other energy firms are slashing dividends, ExxonMobil is entering 2026 with a plan to return $20 billion to shareholders, proving that in a low-price world, scale and efficiency are the ultimate competitive advantages.

Conversely, companies like Albemarle (NYSE: ALB) are in a defensive crouch. As the global leader in lithium, Albemarle has been forced to slash its capital expenditure by 65% over the last two years to preserve cash. While they remain a "strategic survivor" due to their high-quality assets in Nevada and Australia, the current glut has forced them to move away from fixed-price contracts to dynamic pricing models, hoping to capture any sudden 2026 rebounds. In the agricultural space, Archer-Daniels-Midland (NYSE: ADM) is navigating thin margins by pivoting toward the "Bioeconomy." ADM is restructuring to exit low-margin animal nutrition segments and focusing on sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) feedstocks, a move intended to create value-added premiums over traditional, oversupplied grain trading.

The Wider Significance: Geopolitics and the "Dark Fleet"

The 2026 commodity landscape is not just about supply and demand; it is a mirror of a fragmenting geopolitical order. The persistence of high production is increasingly seen as a tool of economic warfare. By keeping prices low, dominant producers like Indonesia (in nickel) and the U.S. (in oil) are effectively "starving" competitors who lack the same subsidies or geological advantages. This trend fits into a broader movement toward "re-globalization," where supply chains are being rerouted to avoid tariff volatility and geopolitical chokepoints.

Furthermore, the rise of the "Dark Fleet"—a shadow network of tankers carrying sanctioned oil from Russia and Iran—continues to distort market signals. These "ghost supplies" keep global inventories higher than official data suggests, complicating the efforts of regulators and central banks to manage inflation. Additionally, the maritime world is bracing for a permanent shift in logistics. With the Suez Canal and Red Sea remaining high-risk zones due to regional instability, shippers are now budgeting for the Cape of Good Hope route as a standard, adding significant lead times and costs that offset some of the benefits of lower commodity prices.

The 2026 Outlook: Shocks on the Horizon

Looking ahead, the primary risk to this era of abundance is a sudden, climate-driven supply shock. Predictive models for 2026 suggest a strong La Niña phase, which historically disrupts harvests in the U.S. Midwest and Brazil while causing flooding in Australian mines. While the market is currently oversupplied, a simultaneous failure in major agricultural and mining hubs could lead to "localized scarcity" and violent price spikes, catching over-leveraged buyers off guard.

In the short term, companies will likely continue their strategic pivots. We expect to see more "green steel" initiatives from miners like Rio Tinto (NYSE: RIO), which is preparing to ship the first major commercial volumes from its Simandou project in Guinea this year. This high-grade iron ore is essential for low-carbon manufacturing, representing a shift from volume-based growth to "purity-based" growth. The challenge for 2026 will be managing the transition from a period of glut to a future where supply is increasingly dictated by carbon footprints and geopolitical alignment.

Summary and Investor Takeaways

The global commodity market of 2026 is defined by a fierce battle for dominance in a low-margin world. The "Production Paradox" has created a landscape where the strongest players are doubling down on output to squeeze out the weak. For investors, the key takeaway is that "low-cost" is no longer just a buzzword; it is a prerequisite for survival. The era of high-beta commodity plays is over, replaced by a focus on operational excellence and balance sheet strength.

Moving forward, the market will be characterized by extreme sensitivity to supply chain disruptions and climate events. Investors should watch for the impact of La Niña on grain prices and any further escalation in trade tariffs that could disrupt the flow of battery metals. While the headline prices remain low, the underlying volatility remains high, making 2026 a year for cautious, quality-focused investing in the resource sector.

This content is intended for informational purposes only and is not financial advice.

title: Chuyển đổi kép giúp Lọc hoá dầu Bình Sơn bứt phá và phát triển bền vững - Bnews.vn
description:
Trang chủ Doanh nghiệp Chuyển đổi kép giúp Lọc hoá dầu Bình Sơn bứt phá và phát triển bền vững Anh Nguyễn/Bnews/vnanet.vn 21:01' - 01/01/2026 Theo dõi Bnews.vn trên News Your browser does not support the audio element.
Doanh nghiệp Hơn 5,3 tỷ USD vào Khu Công nghiệp TP.
Hồ Chí Minh 15:51' Ban Quản lý các khu chế xuất và công nghiệp TP.
Doanh nghiệp Vượt sóng, đón vận hội mới 08:52' Năm 2025 khép lại song cũng mở ra một chương mới đầy kỳ vọng cho cộng đồng doanh nghiệp Việt Nam trong năm 2026.
Doanh nghiệp Doanh nghiệp lữ hành có khách du lịch trốn ở lại nước ngoài sẽ bị phạt tiền 22:00' - 31/12/2025 Quy định này nhằm bảo đảm quyền lợi cho doanh nghiệp và lợi ích của nhà nước trong trường hợp có hành vi vi phạm xảy ra.
text:
Trang chủ

Doanh nghiệp

Chuyển đổi kép giúp Lọc hoá dầu Bình Sơn bứt phá và phát triển bền vững

Anh Nguyễn/Bnews/vnanet.vn 21:01' - 01/01/2026 Theo dõi Bnews.vn trên News

Your browser does not support the audio element.

BNEWS Việc quyết liệt chuyển đổi xanh gắn với chuyển đổi số, BSR không chỉ nâng cao năng lực cạnh tranh, phát triển bền vững mà còn tiếp tục khẳng định vai trò trụ cột bảo đảm an ninh năng lượng quốc gia.

Với việc quyết liệt thực hiện chuyển đổi xanh gắn với chuyển đổi số, Công ty Cổ phần Lọc hoá dầu Bình Sơn (BSR)-đơn vị thành viên của Tập đoàn Công nghiệp-Năng lượng Quốc gia Việt Nam (Petrovietnam) không chỉ nâng cao năng lực cạnh tranh, tạo nền tảng phát triển bền vững mà còn tiếp tục khẳng định vai trò trụ cột trong bảo đảm an ninh năng lượng quốc gia trong giai đoạn mới.

*Chuyển đổi xanh để phát triển bền vững

Tổng Giám đốc BSR Nguyễn Việt Thắng cho biết trước xu hướng chuyển dịch năng lượng toàn cầu và cam kết giảm phát thải carbon (Net zero) của Việt Nam, BSR đã nỗ lực nghiên cứu, phát triển và sản xuất nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững (SAF - Sustainable Aviation Fuel). SAF là sản phẩm được nhà máy lọc dầu Dung Quất của BSR phối trộn từ cấu tử bền vững (SBC/Neat SAF) và Jet A-1, phát triển trên cơ sở tiêu chuẩn xăng máy bay Jet A-1 theo tiêu chuẩn kỹ thuật cho nhiên liệu tuabine hàng không chứa hydrocarbon tổng hợp (tiêu chuẩn ASTM D-7566), đảm bảo chất lượng cho động cơ turbine hàng không.

Đây cũng là sản phẩm nằm trong danh mục sản phẩm chủ lực của Petrovietnam và khẳng định quyết tâm của Petrovietnam trong triển khai Nghị quyết số 57-NQ/TW ngày 22/12/2024 của Bộ Chính trị “về đột phá phát triển khoa học, công nghệ, đổi mới sáng tạo và chuyển đổi số quốc gia”. BSR tự hào là một trong những đơn vị tiên phong triển khai thương mại hóa SAF, hướng tới cung cấp giải pháp năng lượng sạch cho các hãng hàng không trong nước và quốc tế, -ông Nguyễn Việt Thắng nhấn mạnh.

Theo ông Hoàng Thanh Sơn - Trưởng ban Nghiên cứu Phát triển BSR, sản phẩm SAF của BSR đã được tổ chức SGS Germany GmbH (Đức) cấp 2 chứng nhận quan trọng gồm ISCC CORSIA và ISCC EU, xác nhận đạt tiêu chuẩn quốc tế trong phối trộn, sản xuất, lưu trữ và thương mại sản phẩm SAF. Việc sở hữu chứng nhận ISCC giúp BSR đủ điều kiện xuất khẩu sản phẩm SAF ra thị trường quốc tế, đặc biệt là thị trường EU - nơi có các quy định nghiêm ngặt nhất về phát thải và năng lượng tái tạo. Chứng nhận cũng là minh chứng cho nỗ lực của BSR trong việc đáp ứng các tiêu chuẩn sản xuất xanh, bền vững và có trách nhiệm với môi trường, là lợi thế để công ty mở rộng hợp tác và ký kết hợp đồng thương mại với các đối tác yêu cầu cao về tính bền vững. Ngoài ra, sản phẩm SAF cũng được BSR hoàn thiện đầy đủ tài liệu kỹ thuật, quy trình sản xuất, pha chế nội bộ và tiêu chuẩn cơ sở TCCS 23:2024-BSR. BSR đã phối hợp chặt chẽ với Công ty TNHH MTV Nhiên liệu Hàng không Việt Nam (Skypec), các hãng hàng không và đơn vị vận chuyển để thiết lập chuỗi cung ứng SAF khép kín đầu tiên tại Việt Nam, từ nhập khẩu nguyên liệu, phối trộn, kiểm soát chất lượng đến cung ứng cho các công ty nhiên liệu hàng không và cấp phát cho các chuyến bay nội địa, quốc tế. Theo kế hoạch, BSR sẽ triển khai sản xuất các lô SAF quy mô lớn hơn và tiến tới thương mại hóa trong thời gian tới, ông Hoàng Thanh Sơn cho biết.

Theo ông Cao Tuấn Sĩ, Giám đốc nhà máy lọc dầu Dung Quất, nhiên liệu SAF đã được Vietnam Airlines bay thử 1 chuyến Đà Nẵng ra Hà Nội thành công. Hiện BSR đang phối hợp với các bên, tập trung nghiên cứu để hạ giá thành sản phẩm.

Cùng với triển khai sản phẩm nhiên liệu hàng không bền vững, BSR cũng sẽ xuất bán sản phẩm xăng sinh học E10RON95 vào ngày 1/6/2026 tới đây. Để đảm bảo nguyên liệu cồn sinh học ethanol cho pha chế xăng sinh học E10RON95 theo quy định với nhu cầu dự kiến khoảng 300 nghìn m3/tháng, BSR sẽ tăng cường mua cồn Ethanol từ các nhà máy sản xuất cồn sinh học trong nước, nhất là từ các nhà máy trong hệ thống của Công ty Cổ phần Đồng Xanh, ngoài ra sẽ nhập khẩu nếu thiếu.

Ngoài ra, sản phẩm E10RON95 của BSR sẽ được phối trộn thêm các phụ gia để chống phân tách lớp, đảm bảo chất lượng sản phẩm theo Quy chuẩn Việt Nam (QCVN). Hiện BSR cũng đang phối hợp với các bên để sớm khởi động lại Nhà máy nhiên liệu sinh học Dung Quất, nhằm chủ động một phần nguồn nguyên liệu tại chỗ cồn Ethanol phục vụ pha chế xăng E10RON95.

*Chuyển đổi số để nâng cao sức cạnh tranh Cùng với chuyển đổi xanh, BSR đang đẩy mạnh triển khai chuyển đổi số, lấy trí tuệ nhân tạo (AI) và mô hình nhà máy thông minh làm hạt nhân để nâng cao năng lực cạnh tranh và phát triển bền vững. Theo đại diện BSR, việc tiến tới mô hình nhà máy thông minh tại BSR không chỉ là xu hướng mà còn là nhu cầu cấp bách để thực hiện quản trị biến động, từ đó giúp phản ứng nhanh với sự thay đổi của giá dầu thô, sản phẩm và nhu cầu thị trường. Bên cạnh đó, việc tiến tới nhà máy thông minh còn giúp BSR tối ưu hóa vận hành ở công suất cao, đa dạng hóa các loại dầu thô mới đầu vào và giảm tiêu thụ năng lượng, giảm phát thải. Ngoài ra, việc số hóa này còn giúp giải quyết vấn đề già hóa máy móc và nhân sự bằng cách số hóa tri thức, hỗ trợ ra quyết định nhanh chóng và chính xác cũng như giúp ngăn ngừa các sự cố dừng máy ngoài kế hoạch và đảm bảo tính toàn vẹn thiết bị. Để hiện thực hóa mục tiêu chuyển đổi số, BSR đã thành lập Ban Chỉ đạo Chuyển đổi số, phê duyệt Chiến lược phát triển khoa học công nghệ đến năm 2030 và thành lập phòng Chuyển đổi số chuyên trách. Công ty đã triển khai kết nối dữ liệu giữa hệ thống vận hành (OT) và công nghệ thông tin (IT), tạo ra nguồn dữ liệu duy nhất, chuẩn hóa và bảo mật. Đây chính là "nhiên liệu" đầu vào cho các ứng dụng AI. Theo ông Cao Tuấn Sĩ, BSR đã ứng dụng các công cụ như PI Vision và Power BI để theo dõi tổng thể nhà máy lọc dầu Dung Quất, cảnh báo sớm các bất thường và quản trị các công tác bảo dưỡng, chống ăn mòn theo thời gian thực. Nhờ quản trị số, BSR đã duy trì vận hành các phân xưởng ở công suất cao (CDU 118%, RFCC 110%), góp phần tăng doanh thu thêm khoảng 1.540 tỷ đồng. Trong giai đoạn tới, BSR tập trung vào các bài toán AI chuyên sâu để chuyển từ vận hành phản ứng sang quản lý chủ động: Sử dụng AI/ Machine Learning (học máy) để dự báo hỏng hóc cho các thiết bị quan trọng và ăn mòn đỉnh tháp; ứng dụng mô hình Bản sao số (digital Twin) cho các phân xưởng quan trọng nhằm tối ưu hóa vận hành và tiến tới mô hình số hóa toàn diện nhà máy. BSR cũng đặt mục tiêu hình thành trung tâm vận hành số hợp nhất (UDOC) trên cơ sở tích hợp dữ liệu từ sản xuất đến quản trị doanh nghiệp (tài chính, nhân sự, chuỗi cung ứng) trên một nền tảng duy nhất, từ đó giúp lãnh đạo ra quyết định dựa trên phân tích dữ liệu chuyên sâu. Với phương châm "dữ liệu là nền tảng, AI là công cụ, và quản trị hiệu quả là mục tiêu cuối cùng", BSR đang từng bước hình thành hệ sinh thái quản trị thông minh, sẵn sàng cho các mục tiêu phát triển bền vững và hội nhập quốc tế, đại diện BSR cho biết. Năm 2025, BSR đã vận hành nhà máy lọc dầu Dung Quất an toàn, ổn định với công suất bình quân quy đổi lên tới 120%. Công ty cũng tận dụng hiệu quả “cửa sổ cơ hội” khi giá dầu thô giảm trong khi giá sản phẩm không giảm tương ứng, thậm chí có thời điểm đi ngược chiều, qua đó tối ưu hóa biên lợi nhuận. Đặc biệt, BSR chủ động điều hành sản xuất và tiêu thụ bám sát các kịch bản sản xuất kinh doanh được xây dựng và cập nhật thường xuyên theo diễn biến giá dầu và crack spread, từ đó linh hoạt điều chỉnh công suất, gia tăng tồn kho chiến lược và đẩy mạnh tiêu thụ khi thị trường thuận lợi. Nhờ vậy, BSR ước đạt sản lượng 7.907.293 tấn, tương đương 108% kế hoạch quản trị; doanh thu đạt 142.800 tỷ đồng; lợi nhuận trước thuế đạt 4.700 tỷ đồng; nộp ngân sách nhà nước 14.300 tỷ đồng. Những con số này tiếp tục khẳng định vai trò then chốt của BSR trong phát triển kinh tế địa phương cũng như đóng góp vào an ninh năng lượng quốc gia. Với kết quả sản xuất kinh doanh vượt trội, năm 2025, BSR được Petrovietnam vinh danh là đơn vị hoàn thành toàn diện kế hoạch quản trị, đồng thời lọt Top 7 thương hiệu lớn nhất thị trường niêm yết theo bình chọn của Forbes Việt Nam. Đây là sự ghi nhận xứng đáng cho chiến lược vận hành hiệu quả, tư duy quản trị linh hoạt và năng lực cạnh tranh ngày càng được nâng cao của doanh nghiệp.

title: Sri Lanka Honours India's Operation Sagar Bandhu - GKToday
description:
Sri Lanka has formally acknowledged India’s swift and large-scale humanitarian assistance during the devastation caused by Cyclone Ditwah, honouring Indian naval assets for their critical role in rescue and relief operations.
Recognition by Sri Lanka Navy The Sri Lanka Navy honoured eight foreign naval vessels, including two from India, for providing immediate assistance after Cyclone Ditwah struck in late November.
Operation Sagar Bandhu and Relief Scale India launched Operation Sagar Bandhu on the very day Cyclone Ditwah made landfall.
Imporatnt Facts for Exams Operation Sagar Bandhu is India’s humanitarian mission to Sri Lanka after Cyclone Ditwah.
India and Sri Lanka regularly cooperate on maritime security and disaster response.
text:
Sri Lanka has formally acknowledged India’s swift and large-scale humanitarian assistance during the devastation caused by Cyclone Ditwah, honouring Indian naval assets for their critical role in rescue and relief operations. The recognition underlines the depth of regional cooperation at a time when the island nation faced one of its deadliest climate disasters in recent years.

Recognition by Sri Lanka Navy

The Sri Lanka Navy honoured eight foreign naval vessels, including two from India, for providing immediate assistance after Cyclone Ditwah struck in late November. Sri Lanka’s Prime Minister Harini Amarasuriya personally conveyed gratitude to diplomatic representatives of the assisting countries. The cyclone triggered widespread flooding, landslides, and infrastructure collapse, overwhelming national disaster-response systems.

Role of Indian Naval Assets

Indian Navy ships INS Vikrant and INS Udayagiri were among the first foreign vessels to respond. Both ships were initially in Sri Lankan waters to participate in the International Fleet Review 2025 marking the navy’s 75th anniversary. Following the cyclone’s landfall on November 27, these vessels were swiftly redeployed for humanitarian assistance and disaster relief operations.

Operation Sagar Bandhu and Relief Scale

India launched Operation Sagar Bandhu on the very day Cyclone Ditwah made landfall. The mission delivered more than 1,100 tonnes of relief material, including food rations, tents, tarpaulins, clothing, hygiene kits, and water purification equipment. Around 14.5 tonnes of medicines and medical equipment were supplied, along with an additional 60 tonnes of logistical support material. Helicopters deployed from INS Vikrant played a key role in aerial rescue and supply drops.

Imporatnt Facts for Exams

Operation Sagar Bandhu is India’s humanitarian mission to Sri Lanka after Cyclone Ditwah.

INS Vikrant is India’s indigenously built aircraft carrier.

Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Relief (HADR) is a key naval role.

India and Sri Lanka regularly cooperate on maritime security and disaster response.

Wider Assistance and Diplomatic Support
