title: DevvStream, Southern, IP3, and XCF to Evaluate Development of America-First Nuclear ...
description:
We are excited to explore a strategic relationship with XCF, DevvStream, and Southern, including the potential deployment of small modular reactor technology to provide firm power and support e‑SAF production for European markets.
About IP3 Corporation IP3 is a U.S. integrator for the development and operations of peaceful and secure civil nuclear power in the global marketplace.
About Southern Energy Renewables Inc. Southern Energy Renewables Inc. is a U.S.-based clean fuels, chemicals, and products developer focused on advancing large-scale biomass-to-fuels projects.
About XCF Global, Inc. XCF Global, Inc. (“XCF”) is an emerging sustainable aviation fuel company dedicated to accelerating the aviation industry’s transition to net-zero emissions.
DevvStream and Southern may also file other documents with the SEC and Canadian securities regulatory authorities regarding the proposed transaction.
text:
SACRAMENTO, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--DevvStream Corp. (Nasdaq: DEVS) (“DevvStream”), a leading carbon management and environmental-asset monetization firm, today announced a non-binding memorandum of understanding (“MOU”) to evaluate a strategic collaboration focused on small modular reactor (“SMR”) nuclear power development, electro-sustainable aviation fuel (“eSAF”) production, and the creation, verification, and monetization of eligible environmental attributes alongside IP3 Corporation (“IP3”), Southern Energy Renewables Inc. (“Southern”), and XCF Global Inc. (“XCF”) (Nasdaq: SAFX) (together “the parties”).

The MOU outlines a proposed integrated framework to assess the development and deployment of firm, zero-carbon nuclear electricity from SMRs to support clean fuel production and energy-intensive end markets, including AI data centers, while enabling robust environmental-attribute structures that may meet evolving compliance, reporting, and market standards. The MOU also outlines a framework to explore the development and deployment of SMR-generated electricity to support existing and future operating assets, including a potential nuclear power solution for a proposed SAF refinery in Louisiana, and to enable a scalable portfolio of verifiable environmental attributes.

If pursued, the parties intend to advance reliable, zero-carbon nuclear power to enable continuous electrolysis, hydrogen production, and downstream fuel synthesis, while also supporting excess clean-power offtake for third-party customers where appropriate.

The parties also intend to evaluate, as part of the negotiation of definitive agreements, environmental-attribute structures associated with eSAF and related low-carbon fuel pathways, including emerging “book-and-claim” and SAF certificate frameworks that allow airlines and corporate buyers to access verified in-sector emissions reduction attributes when physical fuel delivery is constrained.

In parallel, and pending the execution of definitive agreements, the MOU contemplates future development of digital infrastructure to enhance transparency, provenance, and auditability, including tokenization of eligible environmental assets and the use of digital measurement, reporting, and verification (“MRV”) systems to support data quality, provenance, and auditability.

“Together, we are exploring real-world asset and tokenized environmental-asset frameworks with the potential to unlock additional value, improve liquidity, and help lower the delivered cost of clean energy and fuels,” said Sunny Trinh, Chief Executive Officer of DevvStream. “We see this as a potential America-first model that combines U.S. resources, digital infrastructure, and scalable markets.”

“This MOU reflects our focus on putting American energy, infrastructure, and production first,” said Jay Patel, Chief Executive Officer of Southern Energy Renewables. “As the development of advanced nuclear platforms gains momentum, we believe the goal of developing and deploying firm, domestic power is becoming essential for fuels, manufacturing, and data-driven industries. We are committed to exploring how nuclear power, combined with U.S. biomass resources, can enable an integrated, multi-product approach that strengthens U.S. industrial leadership while remaining globally competitive.”

RDML (Ret.) Mike Hewitt, Chief Executive Officer of IP3, added: “Clean, reliable nuclear power is increasingly being pursued as foundational infrastructure for American energy security and industrial growth. We are excited to explore a strategic relationship with XCF, DevvStream, and Southern, including the potential deployment of small modular reactor technology to provide firm power and support e‑SAF production for European markets. IP3’s business model to develop infrastructure projects to privatize Small Modular Reactors for multiple offtakers such as AI and data centers that support government and commercial requirements. We believe pairing firm power development with practical environmental‑asset design and monetization can create a differentiated platform that meets real customer demand while delivering the transparency the market expects.”

“This MOU reflects XCF’s disciplined approach to evaluating infrastructure and partnerships that can strengthen the scalability, reliability, and carbon performance of next-generation sustainable aviation fuels,” said Chris Cooper, Chief Executive Officer of XCF Global. “We believe firm, zero-carbon power is an important enabler for eSAF pathways, and this collaboration, if ultimately pursued, is expected to allow us to assess how integrated power, fuel, and environmental-attribute frameworks could support broader adoption of clean fuels.”

The MOU reflects a shared intent to negotiate definitive collaboration agreements on SAF and other low-carbon fuel opportunities. Any specific collaboration arrangements, investments, or project development activities described in this release remain subject to confirmatory due diligence, negotiation and execution of definitive agreements, internal corporate approvals, and any required regulatory or permitting approvals.

About DevvStream Corp.

DevvStream Corp. (Nasdaq: DEVS) is a carbon management company focused on the development, investment, and sale of environmental assets worldwide, including carbon credits and renewable energy certificates.

About IP3 Corporation

IP3 is a U.S. integrator for the development and operations of peaceful and secure civil nuclear power in the global marketplace. IP3’s vision is to create thriving, peaceful environments in critical world markets through the development of sustainable energy and security infrastructure via public/private initiatives and industry-led partnerships.

About Southern Energy Renewables Inc.

Southern Energy Renewables Inc. is a U.S.-based clean fuels, chemicals, and products developer focused on advancing large-scale biomass-to-fuels projects. These projects are in development and designed to produce carbon-negative SAF and green methanol, supported by integrated carbon capture and sequestration.

About XCF Global, Inc.

Our flagship facility, New Rise Reno, has a permitted nameplate production capacity of 38 million gallons per year, positioning XCF as an early mover among large-scale SAF producers in North America. XCF is advancing a pipeline of potential expansion opportunities in Nevada, North Carolina, and Florida, and is building partnerships across the energy and transportation sectors to scale SAF globally. XCF is listed on the Nasdaq Capital Market and trades under the ticker, SAFX.

This communication is not a substitute for any proxy statement, registration statement or prospectus, or any other document that DevvStream and Southern (as applicable) may file with the SEC or Canadian securities regulatory authorities in connection with the proposed transaction. title: Evonik wins two patent disputes, reaffirming legal protection for its 3-stage process with ...
description:
Evonik has won two legal disputes, unquestionably securing European Union and U.S. patent rights for the company’s pioneering 3-stage biogas upgrading process with SEPURAN Green membranes.
In two judicially separate, final decisions, the European Patent Office upheld Evonik’s EP3240620 B1 patent and the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office upheld Evonik’s US 10,471,380 B2 patent.
The decisions were issued in each organization’s respective board of appeals, dismissing all requests for invalidation that were filed by other parties.
As a result, both the EPO and USPTO consistently recognize and uphold legal protection for Evonik’s innovative 3-stage process, which was developed by the company’s top experts for the benefit of biogas upgrading customers across the EU, the U.S., and other key global markets.
“We are satisfied with these final decisions as they clearly confirm the unique innovation and technology we offer customers through our membranes and full-system solutions,” says Jennifer Doerper, director of Evonik’s global SEPURAN Green membranes business.
text:
Evonik has won two legal disputes, unquestionably securing European Union and U.S. patent rights for the company’s pioneering 3-stage biogas upgrading process with SEPURAN Green membranes.

In two judicially separate, final decisions, the European Patent Office upheld Evonik’s EP3240620 B1 patent and the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office upheld Evonik’s US 10,471,380 B2 patent. The decisions were issued in each organization’s respective board of appeals, dismissing all requests for invalidation that were filed by other parties. As a result, both the EPO and USPTO consistently recognize and uphold legal protection for Evonik’s innovative 3-stage process, which was developed by the company’s top experts for the benefit of biogas upgrading customers across the EU, the U.S., and other key global markets.

“We are satisfied with these final decisions as they clearly confirm the unique innovation and technology we offer customers through our membranes and full-system solutions,” says Jennifer Doerper, director of Evonik’s global SEPURAN Green membranes business. “We take our commitment to customers seriously and will always defend and enforce our legal rights to ensure all biogas upgrading clients know they are actually receiving the innovative technology and service backed by our cutting-edge experts. To this end, we will work to pursue compliance from industry peers.”

title: A Christmas Stress Test: Why Diesel Pricing Stress Means Profits - MarketBeat
description:
While freight volumes remained relatively soft, indicating that consumers and businesses are spending cautiously, the price of diesel fuel surged.
Valero Energy NYSE: VLO and Phillips 66 NYSE: PSX are uniquely positioned to benefit from this diesel disconnect.
Phillips 66: The Architect of the Squeeze While Valero profits from running hard, Phillips 66 is generating value by actively reshaping the market.
In October 2025, Phillips 66 officially ceased crude processing at its Los Angeles Refinery (Wilmington/Carson).
In response, Phillips 66 launched the Streamline 66 initiative, a plan designed to cut costs and enhance shareholder returns.
text:
Every December, the global supply chain undergoes a massive pressure test known as the Christmas Stress Test.

In a typical year, millions of holiday packages flood the logistics network. This surge usually drives up freight volumes (the amount of goods moving) and fuel demand simultaneously. However, the 2025 holiday season produced a rare and confusing anomaly that has left many investors scratching their heads.

While freight volumes remained relatively soft, indicating that consumers and businesses are spending cautiously, the price of diesel fuel surged. This creates a disconnect in the fundamental laws of supply and demand. Usually, weak demand leads to lower fuel prices. Instead, the cost of moving goods is rising even as the volume of goods moving slows.

For general industrial stocks like FedEx NYSE: FDX or retailers like Amazon NASDAQ: AMZN, this is a distinct warning sign. It suggests higher operating costs and lower profit margins heading into the first quarter of 2026. If it costs more to move fewer products, earnings will suffer.

However, for the companies that manufacture the fuel, this dynamic signals a massive profit windfall. Valero Energy NYSE: VLO and Phillips 66 NYSE: PSX are uniquely positioned to benefit from this diesel disconnect. While the broader economy worries about sticky inflation and logistics costs, these refiners are capitalizing on a market that is structurally short on supply.

The December Crack Back and the Diesel Margin Surge

To understand why these stocks are rising, investors must understand the crack spread. This financial metric represents the difference between the purchase price of crude oil and the selling price of refined products like diesel. It is, essentially, the refiner's gross profit margin.

In the fourth quarter of 2025, markets witnessed a phenomenon that traders are calling the December Crack Back. Margins for Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) in the New York Harbor market skyrocketed, hitting approximately $49 per barrel in late December—more than doubling from the low $20s seen just months prior in October.

This price spike is not driven by booming economic demand; it is driven by a supply shock. Three main factors are currently colliding to keep prices high:

Geopolitics: Tightened sanctions on Russian oil companies such as Rosneft and Lukoil in late 2025 effectively removed a significant volume of diesel from the global export market.

Winter Weather: Diesel fuel and home heating oil are chemically very similar. A cold snap in late 2025 increased demand for heating oil, drawing down the same inventories needed for trucking.

Capacity Cuts: Domestic refiners have permanently closed facilities to reduce costs, leaving the market with fewer barrels to go around.

For the general economy, high fuel prices during a freight recession increase the risk of a hard landing in 2026. However, for the refining sector, this supply shortage creates a high profit floor. Even if fewer trucks are on the road, the profit earned on every gallon of diesel sold remains historically high.

Valero Energy: The Operational Powerhouse

If the market is short on diesel, the company with the most functioning capacity stands to win the most.

Valero Energy has emerged as the clear operator's choice in this environment. The stock has outperformed the broader energy sector, gaining approximately 35% year-to-date.

Valero’s strategy is simple: operational excellence. While competitors have struggled with complicated restructurings, Valero has focused on running its machinery as efficiently as possible. In the third quarter of 2025, the company reported earnings per share (EPS) of $3.66, beating analyst expectations.

The key to Valero’s success is utilization. Their refineries have been running at near 97% capacity. In a market where margins are $49 per barrel, keeping utilization high translates directly into massive free cash flow.

Furthermore, Valero isn't just relying on old-school oil. The company is a leader in the transition to green energy through Diamond Green Diesel (DGD), its joint venture with Darling Ingredients. The expansion at their Port Arthur facility, completed earlier in 2025, allows them to produce Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). This creates a diversified revenue stream that appeals to investors looking for longevity. Valero captures the immediate upside of the diesel shortage while maintaining a foothold in the future of energy.

Phillips 66: The Architect of the Squeeze

While Valero profits from running hard, Phillips 66 is generating value by actively reshaping the market. In fact, Phillips 66 is partially responsible for the current high margins enjoyed by the entire industry.

In October 2025, Phillips 66 officially ceased crude processing at its Los Angeles Refinery (Wilmington/Carson). This move removed approximately 139,000 barrels per day of supply from the West Coast market. By taking this supply offline, Phillips 66 tightened the local market, driving up prices for the fuel produced by its remaining assets.

This aggressive decision-making is primarily driven by pressure from activist investor Elliott Investment Management, which has pushed the company to improve performance. In response, Phillips 66 launched the Streamline 66 initiative, a plan designed to cut costs and enhance shareholder returns.

The company has successfully executed this strategy, exceeding its $3 billion asset divestiture goal by late 2025, including the sale of its stake in a Swiss retail business and various pipeline assets.

Investment firm Raymond James maintained an Outperform rating on the stock in late December, citing the success of these self-help measures. For investors, Phillips 66 is a strategic play. It offers value through cost-cutting, share buybacks, and a more efficient portfolio, rather than just raw production volume.

2026 Outlook: How to Position Your Portfolio

The 2025 Christmas Stress Test has clarified the investment landscape for the new year. The global economy is facing a structural shortage of diesel refining capacity. This shortage insulates refiners from the economic headwinds that might hurt other industrial sectors.

Investors looking to trade this disconnect have two clear paths:

The Offensive Play: Valero Energy is the vehicle for immediate exposure to high profit margins. Their high utilization rates and established renewable diesel operations make them the primary beneficiary of the current price environment.

The Strategic Play: Phillips 66 offers a compelling narrative of restructuring. By closing high-cost assets like the LA refinery and satisfying activist demands, they are unlocking value on the balance sheet rather than just the income statement.

As we move into 2026, the data indicates that while the cost of shipping goods may remain a burden for the economy, the companies producing the fuel remain a bright spot for portfolios.

title: CALC Orders 30 More Airbus A320neo Family Jets - Airways Magazine
description:
‍TOULOUSE — China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Limited (CALC) has firmed an order for 30 Airbus A320neo Family aircraft, further expanding one of the largest Airbus portfolios among global lessors.
The agreement marks CALC’s fifth commitment with Airbus, bringing its total Airbus backlog to 282 aircraft, including 203 A320neo-family jets.
Airbus EVP Sales Benoît de Saint-Exupéry described CALC as a long-standing and valued partner whose repeat commitments underscore the A320neo’s market strength.
The faithful A320neo remains the world’s most-ordered single-aisle family with more than 19,000 commitments worldwide.
All Airbus aircraft are currently certified to operate on up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), with the manufacturer targeting 100% SAF capability by 2030.
text:
‍TOULOUSE — China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Limited (CALC) has firmed an order for 30 Airbus A320neo Family aircraft, further expanding one of the largest Airbus portfolios among global lessors.

The agreement marks CALC’s fifth commitment with Airbus, bringing its total Airbus backlog to 282 aircraft, including 203 A320neo-family jets.

CALC Chief Executive Mike Poon said the new order reflects both continued customer demand and the lessor’s commitment to fleet modernisation. Airbus EVP Sales Benoît de Saint-Exupéry described CALC as a long-standing and valued partner whose repeat commitments underscore the A320neo’s market strength.

The faithful A320neo remains the world’s most-ordered single-aisle family with more than 19,000 commitments worldwide. Airbus says the type delivers at least 20% lower fuel burn and CO₂ emissions versus the previous-generation A320ceo, while offering one of the widest cabins in the single-aisle segment.

All Airbus aircraft are currently certified to operate on up to 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), with the manufacturer targeting 100% SAF capability by 2030.

CALC’s follow-on order reinforces two clear industry trends: lessors continue to dominate new-aircraft placements, owning over 50% of the global commercial aircraft fleet, and demand for efficient single-aisle jets remains exceptionally strong, particularly in Asia, one of the fastest-growing aviation markets where traffic growth and airline fleet renewal are accelerating as international demand normalizes.

title: Chinese leasing firm CALC orders 30 Airbus A320neo planes - France 24
description:
The firm order, the fifth that CALC has placed with Airbus, brings the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the European aircraft manufacturer to 282, including 203 A320neo family aircraft.
CALC chief executive Mike Poon said in the statement that the order will allow it to "continue providing our airline customers worldwide with high-value, modern aircraft solutions".
As of June the company owned and managed 181 aircraft and counted 41 airlines in 22 countries as clients.
The A320neo family is the latest generation of the single-aisle, medium-haul aircraft, offering greater fuel economy and the ability to burn up to 50 percent sustainable aviation fuel.
Together with Boeing's 737 family of aircraft, the A320s are the workhorses of the commercial airline industry.
text:
The firm order, the fifth that CALC has placed with Airbus, brings the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the European aircraft manufacturer to 282, including 203 A320neo family aircraft.

CALC chief executive Mike Poon said in the statement that the order will allow it to "continue providing our airline customers worldwide with high-value, modern aircraft solutions".

The value of the contract was not disclosed. Airbus has not published list prices for aircraft since 2018. CALC said the aircraft would be delivered through 2033.

As of June the company owned and managed 181 aircraft and counted 41 airlines in 22 countries as clients.

The A320neo family is the latest generation of the single-aisle, medium-haul aircraft, offering greater fuel economy and the ability to burn up to 50 percent sustainable aviation fuel.

Together with Boeing's 737 family of aircraft, the A320s are the workhorses of the commercial airline industry.

title: MB Energy begins SAF supply at Copenhagen Airport : The Daily Digest
description:
In the UK, SAF Investor reported that energy supplier MB Energy said it has begun supply jet fuel and HEFA SPK blend sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) to airlines at Copenhagen Airport in Denmark.
The company said it has invested into the airport fuel infrastructure to access the airport, according to the report.
“This investment underscores our commitment to help enhancing the aviation supply chains in Denmark, as well as across Europe”, says Simon Weiss, head of aviation at MB Energy.
“We look forward to continuing our work in the aviation sector, ensuring that we fuel both today’s and tomorrow’s journeys by working hand in hand with our customers and partners.” MB Energy will also be supplying SAF to customers at the airport, the report added.

title: Researchers aim to produce SAF from tomato residues : The Daily Digest
description:
In Austria, Eurasia Review reported that the EU project ToFuel is developing a new biorefinery concept that will convert tomato residues into sustainable aviation fuel as well as into fertilizer, animal feed and nutritional oil.
Under the leadership of Graz University of Technology (TU Graz), the research team is aiming for a waste-free and climate-neutral process that is also economically competitive.

text:
In Austria, Eurasia Review reported that the EU project ToFuel is developing a new biorefinery concept that will convert tomato residues into sustainable aviation fuel as well as into fertilizer, animal feed and nutritional oil. Under the leadership of Graz University of Technology (TU Graz), the research team is aiming for a waste-free and climate-neutral process that is also economically competitive.

“According to estimates, around three per cent of the sustainable aviation fuels required in Europe by 2030 could be covered from the amount of tomato pomace produced throughout the EU, i.e. the residues from tomato processing,” explains project manager Marlene Kienberger from the Institute of Chemical Engineering and Environmental Technology at TU Graz.

In order to turn tomato waste into a high-quality fuel, the biomass must first be processed so that microorganisms can utilize it efficiently. ToFuel is investigating two modern fractionation technologies. During extrusion, the biomass is treated under heat and pressure and then broken down into its cellular components by an abrupt drop in pressure. This creates an optimally digested biomass for the subsequent fermentation process, in which microorganisms produce lipids that are later processed into aviation fuel. In the second fractionation technology, hydrothermal liquefaction, the biomass is converted into bio-oil and biochar under high pressure and at high temperatures, according to the report.

title: Sustainable aviation fuel take-up in UK unlikely to hit 2025 target, official data shows
description:
In the UK, The Guardian reported that the take-up of SAF is on course to fall short of the UK government’s first annual mandate.
Production data published by the Department for Transport (DfT) covering most of 2025 shows that sustainable fuels (SAF) only accounted for 1.6% of fuel supplied for UK flights – 20% less fuel in volume than the 2% needed to fulfill the requirement.
The report noted that the government introduced the mandate in January, which requires suppliers to hit targets for SAF – which the industry has argued is important for cutting its carbon emissions – within the overall UK aviation fuel mix.
The mandatory target rises sharply from 2% in 2025 to 10% in 2030 and then to 22% in 2040, including the use of second-generation fuels that are seen as more sustainable in the long term, the report added.
So far, the supply of SAF has been exclusively produced from recycled cooking oil from Asia, predominantly China, the DfT figures showed.
text:

The mandatory target rises sharply from 2% in 2025 to 10% in 2030 and then to 22% in 2040, including the use of second-generation fuels that are seen as more sustainable in the long term, the report added.

So far, the supply of SAF has been exclusively produced from recycled cooking oil from Asia, predominantly China, the DfT figures showed.

title: What to Know About Delta Air Lines Medallion Status in 2026 | Luxury Travel Advisor
description:
As a Centennial year for the books begins to wind down, Delta Air Lines’ SkyMiles members are making their final moves to secure 2026 Medallion Status before December 31.
With Medallion Qualification Dollars (MQD) thresholds to qualify for 2027 Medallion Status staying the same, members can earn toward elite status with no added requirements.
Updates to Choice Benefits Diamond and Platinum Medallion members enjoy access to exclusive Choice Benefits—customizable options designed to reflect what matters most to each of Delta’s most loyal members.
Beginning February 1, 2026, members will see the following changes to 2026 Choice Benefits options: For members who select Choice Benefits at the lower value prior to February 1, 2026, Delta will deposit the difference by mid-February 2026.
Return of Elevate Your Status Elevate Your Status is back by popular demand, giving members more flexibility and control over how to secure their 2026 Medallion Status.
text:
As a Centennial year for the books begins to wind down, Delta Air Lines’ SkyMiles members are making their final moves to secure 2026 Medallion Status before December 31. From refreshed Choice Benefits to the return of Elevate Your Status and everyday ways to earn beyond the flight, SkyMiles is giving members more flexibility, more value and more ways to personalize their loyalty experience. With Medallion Qualification Dollars (MQD) thresholds to qualify for 2027 Medallion Status staying the same, members can earn toward elite status with no added requirements. Here’s what to know as you plan your final flights, vacations and purchases of 2025.

Updates to Choice Benefits

Diamond and Platinum Medallion members enjoy access to exclusive Choice Benefits—customizable options designed to reflect what matters most to each of Delta’s most loyal members. Beginning February 1, 2026, members will see the following changes to 2026 Choice Benefits options:

For members who select Choice Benefits at the lower value prior to February 1, 2026, Delta will deposit the difference by mid-February 2026. For those who select Choice Benefits at the higher statement credit values prior to their decrease on February 1, 2026, no adjustments will be made, and they will receive the higher statement credit value. All other exclusive Choice Benefits options remain unchanged.

Whether members are aiming to reach Medallion Status for the first time, leveling up to the next tier or making a comeback, there’s still time to make it happen before December 31. Here are a few smart ways to make the most of the final stretch: fly with Delta and partner airlines; use Delta SkyMiles American Express Card; and book a Delta Vacations package.

Return of Elevate Your Status

Elevate Your Status is back by popular demand, giving members more flexibility and control over how to secure their 2026 Medallion Status. Through December 31, eligible U.S.-based SkyMiles and Medallion Members can make a one-time MQD purchase to reach the next Medallion tier for 2026.

The limited-time program returns with a meaningful update: 100 percent of proceeds (excluding processing fees) will go directly toward funding sustainable aviation fuel (SAF)—a certified alternative jet fuel that can reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 80 percent compared to conventional jet fuel.

No change to MQD thresholds for 2027 Status

In case you missed it, MQD thresholds to qualify for 2027 Medallion Status are staying the same—so members can look forward to earning toward Diamond, Platinum, Gold and Silver Medallion Status without any added requirements next year.

Need a Status check? The app makes it easy to stay on top of your SkyMiles journey as your go-to tool for tracking MQDs and progress toward achieving the next Medallion Tier.

The company plans to use waste biomass from Nova Scotia forestry and forest-based industries to create low-emission aviation fuel as an alternative to petroleum-based fuel.

text:
Nova Sustainable Fuels has received environmental assessment approval for the first phase of a project that will see the company develop a renewable energy park in Goldboro, Guysborough County, where it will produce sustainable aviation fuel.

The company plans to use waste biomass from Nova Scotia forestry and forest-based industries to create low-emission aviation fuel as an alternative to petroleum-based fuel.

“Projects like this are crucial to helping to reduce global carbon emissions, while creating jobs and growing our economy,” said Timothy Halman, Minister of Environment and Climate Change. “And when we welcome projects like this, it continues to position Nova Scotia as a leader in climate change action, innovation and the global clean energy transformation.”

The company will need a second environmental assessment approval for its second phase – a proposed wind energy and solar farm and a transmission line to supply renewable energy for fuel production.

title: Bunge Brazil certifies sustainable soybeans for SAF - World-Grain.com
description:
SÃO PAULO, BRAZIL — Bunge Global SA’s crush facility in Rondonópolis, Mato Grosso, Brazil, has received a certification for its soybeans used in the production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) that verifies low risk of indirect land use change (LUC).
The SCS Global Services certification under the international ISCC CORSIA PLUS protocol is recognized by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).
The certification employs rigorous sustainability standards that verified Brazilian soybeans must meet, based on traceability and other agricultural practices, said Bunge, which noted that it is the first company to certify soybeans under the protocol.
“This certification demonstrates that it is possible to produce soybeans sustainably and with low emissions, meeting the most demanding international criteria,” said Pamela Moreira, sustainability director for South America at Bunge.
“Beyond detailed technical criteria and rigorous audits, producer management practices play a fundamental role in this certification,” Moreira said.
text:
SÃO PAULO, BRAZIL — Bunge Global SA’s crush facility in Rondonópolis, Mato Grosso, Brazil, has received a certification for its soybeans used in the production of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) that verifies low risk of indirect land use change (LUC).

The SCS Global Services certification under the international ISCC CORSIA PLUS protocol is recognized by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). Certification includes the ISCC CORSIA PLUS Low-LUC seal.

The certification employs rigorous sustainability standards that verified Brazilian soybeans must meet, based on traceability and other agricultural practices, said Bunge, which noted that it is the first company to certify soybeans under the protocol.

“This certification demonstrates that it is possible to produce soybeans sustainably and with low emissions, meeting the most demanding international criteria,” said Pamela Moreira, sustainability director for South America at Bunge. “Brazil’s vast productive potential and advanced agricultural techniques represent significant potential to contribute to the energy transition. This achievement reinforces that sustainably grown soybeans can be part of the solution for the advancement of agroforestry systems.”

The ISCC CORSIA PLUS certification is part of the CORSIA (Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation) program, created to encourage the use of renewable fuels in global air transportation.

The Low-LUC recognition guarantees that the certified soybeans, through improved management and productivity practices, present a low risk of indirect land-use change, meaning they are not associated with new agricultural area expansion, Bunge said.

“Beyond detailed technical criteria and rigorous audits, producer management practices play a fundamental role in this certification,” Moreira said. “This reinforces our journey of having an active role in our supply chain, engaging and supporting our producers in this transition, but also connecting them with new opportunities.

“We are aware of the challenges in scaling this certification and, therefore, its result has great weight for the sector, reinforcing the credibility of Brazilian agricultural production. Although this initial certification applies to our Rondonópolis unit, it represents a fundamental step in expanding the availability of soybean raw material for the growing SAF market.”

St. Louis, Missouri, US-based Bunge, the world’s largest oilseeds processor, operates more than 100 locations throughout Brazil, including processing, refining, bottling and storage units, and port terminals.

title: Tallow Trade Faces Major Disruption from US Policy Shifts - Discovery Alert
description:
Furthermore, tallow trade affected by US policy shifts has become a defining characteristic of modern commodity markets.
Modern tallow markets operate within a complex three-tier classification system based on disease risk assessment.
What Policy Changes Are Driving Tallow Trade Disruption?
Tallow trade affected by US policy shifts requires market participants to develop comprehensive regulatory intelligence capabilities, incorporating policy monitoring, compliance cost analysis, and strategic planning for multiple regulatory scenarios.
Trade policy shifts continue reshaping traditional trade relationships and commercial strategies throughout the renewable energy sector.
text:
Understanding Tallow Trade Fundamentals

The global renewable energy transition has fundamentally altered traditional commodity markets, with animal-derived feedstocks emerging as critical components in biofuel production pathways. Tallow, classified as an animal by-product under international trade regulations, represents one of the most significant feedstocks in this transformation, bridging agricultural waste streams with advanced fuel technologies. Furthermore, tallow trade affected by US policy shifts has become a defining characteristic of modern commodity markets.

Modern tallow markets operate within a complex three-tier classification system based on disease risk assessment. Categories 1 and 2 tallow qualify for Tallow Methyl Ester (TME) production and benefit from double-counting mechanisms under specific renewable energy frameworks, while Category 3 tallow serves as the primary input for Hydrotreated Vegetable Oil (HVO) Class III and Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) production.

Regional production centers have established distinct competitive advantages based on livestock density and processing infrastructure. Australian facilities benefit from record feedlot capacity of 1.7 million head with slaughter rates increasing nearly 10% year-on-year, while Brazilian operations have historically dominated export markets through integrated supply chains connecting cattle ranching with biodiesel refineries.

The commodity's unique properties create natural price correlations with competing feedstocks, particularly used cooking oil and soybean oil derivatives. These relationships generate complex arbitrage opportunities across geographic markets, with pricing differentials reflecting transportation costs, regulatory compliance requirements, and local mandates for renewable fuel blending.

What Policy Changes Are Driving Tallow Trade Disruption?

US Tariff Implementation Framework

Washington's implementation of a 50% composite tariff on Brazilian tallow imports, effective August 2025, represents the most significant policy intervention reshaping global trade flows. This tariff structure operates alongside the 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit, which creates preferential treatment for North American feedstocks while reducing eligibility for foreign materials.

The tariff's impact became immediately apparent in bilateral trade data, with Brazilian exports to the US dropping sharply from September 2025 onwards. Previously, Brazil supplied 96% of US tallow imports in 2024, according to trade statistics from the US Department of Agriculture, making this policy shift particularly disruptive to established supply chains.

Additional regulatory uncertainty stems from potential modifications to Renewable Identification Number (RIN) credits. Reports suggest the US EPA may indefinitely delay proposals to halve RIN credits for biofuels produced from foreign feedstocks, creating ongoing market speculation about future incentive structures.

The 45Z credit mechanism introduces sliding-scale incentives based on carbon intensity scoring, with soybean-based biodiesel eligible for approximately 32¢/USG in 2025, projected to increase to approximately 64¢/USG in 2026 as indirect land-use change penalties are removed from the calculation framework.

Comparative Policy Landscape Analysis

Table: Regional Policy Implementation Timeline and Trade Impact

Region Policy Mechanism Implementation Status Feedstock Treatment United States 50% Brazilian tariffs + 45Z credits Active August 2025 Domestic preference structure European Union RED III transposition January 2026 rollout Category-based restrictions Australia Cleaner Fuels Programme Mid-2026 launch A$1.1 billion stimulus package Netherlands 0.5 multiplication factor 2026 implementation Category 3 limitations France Category 3 caps 2027 scheduled Volume restrictions planned Germany GHG quota exclusions Currently active Category 3 complete exclusion

European Union member states demonstrate significant divergence in RED III transposition approaches, creating regulatory arbitrage opportunities across jurisdictions. Nordic countries, France, Italy, and Spain maintain higher utilisation rates for Category 3 volumes, while Germany excludes Category 3 entirely from greenhouse gas reduction quotas.

This fragmented implementation creates uneven demand signals for 2026, with southern and Nordic markets remaining active buyers while northern European ports face restricted access for specific tallow categories. Consequently, the resulting compliance complexity forces market participants to develop jurisdiction-specific certification pathways and documentation systems.

Australia's A$1.1 billion Cleaner Fuels Programme represents a different policy approach, focusing on domestic demand stimulus rather than trade restrictions. Industry participants hope this initiative will precede a federal biofuels mandate, providing long-term investment certainty through guaranteed offtake mechanisms.

How Are Regional Regulatory Frameworks Affecting Market Access?

European Union Compliance Complexity

The EU's animal by-products regulation establishes a sophisticated risk-based categorisation system that directly impacts market access and pricing dynamics. Categories 1 and 2, listed in RED III Annex IX Part B, benefit from double-counting mechanisms in specific member states, enhancing their carbon credit value and market competitiveness.

This regulatory framework creates material compliance costs through mandatory chain of custody certification, carbon intensity calculations, and third-party verification of feedstock origins. The documentation requirements extend throughout the supply chain, from slaughter facilities to end-use refineries, creating barriers to entry for smaller market participants.

Member state discretion in RED III transposition has generated significant regulatory divergence. The Netherlands plans to apply a 0.5 multiplication factor from 2026, effectively reducing the volume of qualifying tallow, while France plans caps on Category 3 tallow from 2027. These restrictions contrast sharply with southern and Nordic markets that maintain more accommodating frameworks.

Regulatory Arbitrage Opportunities

The multiplication factor mechanism creates immediate arbitrage opportunities for exporters capable of navigating multiple jurisdictions. Tallow volumes that face restrictions in Germany or the Netherlands retain full value in France, Italy, or Spain, incentivising sophisticated logistics and certification strategies.

The fragmented EU regulatory approach creates complex compliance requirements for market participants, with divergence between ambitious renewable fuel targets and member state restrictions generating inefficiencies throughout the supply chain.

Carbon intensity scoring methodologies vary significantly across member states, creating additional complexity for international traders. These variations reflect different approaches to lifecycle assessment calculations, transportation emissions accounting, and sustainability criteria verification processes.

The double-counting benefit available for Categories 1 and 2 in certain jurisdictions creates premium pricing opportunities compared to Category 3 materials, despite similar technical specifications. This regulatory distinction drives market segmentation and influences production planning at rendering facilities worldwide.

Where Are Tallow Flows Being Redirected Due to Policy Barriers?

Asian Market Absorption Capacity

Singapore has emerged as the primary destination for redirected tallow flows, receiving 27% of Australian exports in the year to September 2025. This consolidation reflects Singapore's role as a regional hub for renewable fuel production and its favourable regulatory treatment of animal-derived feedstocks.

The Asian market's absorption capacity has been enhanced by substantial growth in Chinese used cooking oil methyl ester (UCOME) flows. Chinese exports to Singapore reached 180,122 tonnes through October 2025, already exceeding the full-year 2024 total of 173,340 tonnes. This growth pattern indicates robust regional demand for renewable feedstock blending.

Price competitiveness drives much of this regional reallocation, with B30 delivered Singapore values averaging $732.58/tonne between April and December 2025, compared to $792.90/tonne for B30 UCOME delivered to Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp over the same period. This $60.32/tonne discount reflects both transportation advantages and reduced regulatory compliance costs in Asian markets.

Sustainable Aviation Fuel production represents an emerging demand driver throughout the region, though pricing competitiveness remains the primary determinant of feedstock selection. In addition, regional SAF mandates and carbon pricing mechanisms are still developing, creating future upside potential for tallow demand growth.

Brazilian Market Rebalancing Strategies

Brazilian domestic absorption has increased dramatically following US market access restrictions, with tallow utilisation by the biodiesel industry rising from 5% in July 2025 to 9.5% in October 2025. This rapid adjustment demonstrates the domestic industry's capacity to absorb volumes previously destined for export markets.

Seasonal demand dynamics continue to influence Brazilian market patterns, with November 2025 experiencing cooling demand due to typical drops in diesel consumption. However, tallow prices remained high compared to Australian alternatives, limiting export competitiveness to alternative markets despite improved domestic absorption.

Soybean oil price correlation creates additional complexity for Brazilian exporters, as tallow pricing tends to track soy oil movements. Industry participants anticipate that projected declines in soybean oil prices could potentially restore export economics viability, particularly for EU-certified material destined for European markets.

Brazilian exporters are strategically positioning for potential early 2026 EU shipments by acquiring necessary sustainability certifications. This preparation reflects expectations that European demand will strengthen as RED III implementation creates tighter supply-demand balances across member states.

What Compliance Challenges Are Emerging for Market Participants?

Certification and Traceability Requirements

Contemporary compliance frameworks require comprehensive documentation systems spanning the entire supply chain. Chain of custody certification must track material flows from origin through processing, while carbon intensity calculations demand sophisticated lifecycle assessment capabilities that many smaller participants struggle to implement cost-effectively.

Third-party verification requirements add another layer of complexity and expense, with accredited auditors necessary to validate sustainability claims. These requirements create material transaction costs that favour larger, vertically integrated operations capable of spreading compliance expenses across substantial volume throughput.

Documentation standards vary significantly across jurisdictions, forcing international traders to maintain multiple certification pathways simultaneously. EU sustainability criteria differ from US EPA requirements, while Asian markets often rely on less stringent documentation, creating operational complexity for global market participants.

Carbon intensity scoring methodologies represent particularly challenging technical requirements, with different calculation approaches determining tax credit eligibility across various markets. These methodologies require specialised expertise and sophisticated data management systems that create barriers to market entry.

Risk Management Framework Development

The evolving regulatory landscape demands sophisticated risk management approaches that traditional commodity trading frameworks cannot adequately address. Policy risk exposure requires hedging strategies that account for potential changes in tariff structures, credit eligibility, and certification requirements.

Long-term contract negotiations have become increasingly challenging due to regulatory uncertainty. Standard force majeure clauses may not adequately protect against policy changes that fundamentally alter market access or economic viability of specific trade routes.

Basis differential expansion between regions reflects increasing policy divergence and compliance costs. Forward curve volatility during policy transition periods creates additional pricing complexity that requires enhanced analytical capabilities and more sophisticated trading strategies.

Tallow trade affected by US policy shifts requires market participants to develop comprehensive regulatory intelligence capabilities, incorporating policy monitoring, compliance cost analysis, and strategic planning for multiple regulatory scenarios.

How Are Investment Decisions Being Influenced by Policy Uncertainty?

Capital Allocation Impacts

Investment decision frameworks must now incorporate policy risk assessment as a primary variable in project evaluation. The 45Z credit structure's sliding scale approach creates uncertainty about future incentive values, complicating long-term investment planning for domestic US biofuel production facilities.

Australian market participants await clarity on biofuel mandate implementation following the Cleaner Fuels Programme launch. Industry hopes for federal mandate follow-through reflect recognition that guaranteed offtake mechanisms are typically required for final investment decisions in capital-intensive renewable fuel projects.

European renewable fuel obligation variations across member states influence regional processing capacity development decisions. However, investors must evaluate not only current regulatory frameworks but also anticipated harmonisation efforts and potential policy convergence scenarios over project lifecycles.

Transportation infrastructure adaptation requires substantial capital commitment with uncertain policy-dependent returns. Pipeline systems, storage facilities, and port infrastructure investments must account for potential trade flow redirections based on evolving regulatory landscapes.

Strategic Planning Considerations

Vertical integration trends reflect efforts to reduce exposure to regulatory arbitrage and compliance complexity. Domestic feedstock preference driving consolidation creates competitive advantages for integrated operations capable of controlling supply chains from source to end-use.

Geographic diversification strategies must balance market access opportunities against compliance cost variations. Furthermore, companies are developing multi-jurisdictional approaches that maintain flexibility to redirect volumes based on regulatory changes and market conditions.

Technology investment priorities increasingly focus on compliance automation and data management systems. Carbon intensity tracking capabilities and certification workflow management represent essential infrastructure investments for sustained market participation.

What Market Structure Changes Are Policy Shifts Creating?

Vertical Integration Trends

The regulatory complexity is accelerating industry consolidation as smaller participants struggle with compliance costs and documentation requirements. Vertically integrated operations gain competitive advantages through scale economies in certification processes and enhanced supply chain control.

Regional processing capacity development reflects policy incentives favouring domestic production. US tariff impacts benefit facilities through 45Z credit eligibility restrictions on foreign feedstocks, while European plants must navigate member state variations in category restrictions and multiplication factors.

Supply chain diversification imperatives drive investment in multiple geographic sourcing options. Companies are establishing procurement relationships across different regulatory jurisdictions to maintain flexibility as policy landscapes evolve.

Price Discovery Mechanism Evolution

Traditional pricing benchmarks face challenges from regulatory fragmentation and compliance cost variations. Basis differential expansion between regions reflects not only transportation costs but also regulatory compliance expenses and market access restrictions.

Forward curve construction must incorporate policy risk premiums that reflect potential regulatory changes. Commodity market volatility in pricing models becomes essential for accurate valuation in an environment of heightened policy uncertainty.

Transaction cost increases from compliance requirements affect market liquidity and price discovery efficiency. The additional documentation and verification steps create friction that favours larger transactions and longer-term contractual relationships.

Strategic Outlook for 2026-2027

Policy Convergence Scenarios

US RIN credit modifications remain under consideration, with potential implications for foreign feedstock competitiveness. Indefinite delay reports create ongoing uncertainty that affects long-term planning and investment decisions across the industry.

EU member state harmonisation prospects depend on European Commission guidance and political coordination efforts. Tariff trade disruptions in some jurisdictions create temporary arbitrage opportunities while increasing overall market uncertainty.

Asia-Pacific regulatory framework development remains in early stages, with significant potential for future policy intervention as regional governments pursue carbon reduction targets and energy security objectives.

Market Efficiency Implications

The increasing complexity of regulatory compliance creates material efficiency losses through transaction cost increases and regional price divergence. These inefficiencies may persist until policy frameworks achieve greater stability and harmonisation.

Long-term supply security considerations drive strategic stockpiling and diversified sourcing strategies that may not represent optimal economic allocation but provide risk mitigation against policy disruptions.

Carbon pricing mechanism integration across jurisdictions represents a potential pathway toward policy convergence, though implementation timelines and technical specifications remain uncertain across major markets.

Risk Assessment Framework

Key Policy Risk Factors

Regulatory implementation delays creating extended market uncertainty

Bilateral trade agreement modifications affecting established tariff structures

Sustainability criteria evolution impacting certification costs and requirements

Carbon pricing mechanism integration introducing new compliance variables

Market participants must develop sophisticated regulatory intelligence capabilities that monitor policy developments across multiple jurisdictions while maintaining operational flexibility to adapt to changing requirements. The tariffs and economic implications demonstrate how rapidly evolving regulatory frameworks can fundamentally alter established commercial relationships and require strategic repositioning.

The transformation reflects broader trends toward domestic energy security prioritisation and sustainability compliance integration throughout commodity supply chains. For instance, according to Reuters analysis, the impact on Brazilian exporters has forced significant strategic realignments. Success in this environment requires not only technical expertise in feedstock processing and logistics but also comprehensive understanding of regulatory evolution and policy implementation dynamics across major markets.

Success in this environment requires technical expertise in feedstock processing and logistics as well as comprehensive understanding of regulatory evolution and policy implementation dynamics across major markets. Trade policy shifts continue reshaping traditional trade relationships and commercial strategies throughout the renewable energy sector.

Disclaimer: This analysis is based on publicly available information and market reports. Policy frameworks continue evolving, and readers should verify current regulatory requirements with appropriate authorities before making investment or operational decisions.

title: Airbus secures new 30-jet order from Chinese leasing company - Deeside.com
description:
China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Limited (CALC) has signed a firm order with Airbus for 30 A320neo Family aircraft as it moves to meet growing demand from its airline customers.
The deal marks the Hong Kong-based lessor’s fifth order with Airbus, bringing the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the manufacturer to 282.
Of these, 203 are from the A320neo Family.
CALC’s deep understanding of the market and what its customers demand is a solid endorsement of the A320neo Family.
The A320 Family includes the larger A321neo, which offers extended range and capacity for airlines seeking to operate longer routes with lower fuel use.
text:
China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Limited (CALC) has signed a firm order with Airbus for 30 A320neo Family aircraft as it moves to meet growing demand from its airline customers.

The deal marks the Hong Kong-based lessor’s fifth order with Airbus, bringing the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the manufacturer to 282. Of these, 203 are from the A320neo Family.

Mike Poon, Executive Director and Chief Executive Officer of CALC, said: “Our enduring partnership with Airbus has been central to CALC’s growth. This latest order reflects our shared vision for innovation and sustainable aviation. We are proud to grow alongside Airbus and to continue providing our airline customers worldwide with high-value, modern aircraft solutions.”

Benoît de Saint-Exupéry, Airbus Executive Vice President Sales for Commercial Aircraft, said: “CALC has been a long-time valued partner of Airbus with its first order placed in 2012, and it’s a privilege to see another repeat order. CALC’s deep understanding of the market and what its customers demand is a solid endorsement of the A320neo Family. This commitment reinforces their strength as a lessor with the most efficient, versatile, and in-demand single-aisle aircraft for their customers.”

The A320 Family is the world’s most popular single-aisle aircraft series, with more than 19,000 orders worldwide. The aircraft provide at least 20 per cent fuel savings and CO₂ reductions compared with previous-generation models.

Airbus says all A320 Family aircraft are currently certified to operate with up to 50 per cent Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), and it aims for its full fleet to be capable of operating on 100 per cent SAF by 2030.

The A320 Family includes the larger A321neo, which offers extended range and capacity for airlines seeking to operate longer routes with lower fuel use.

The latest order continues Airbus’s strong global sales performance into 2026, reinforcing demand for fuel-efficient aircraft across the leasing and airline markets.

The wings for all A320 Family aircraft, including those in this order, are designed and assembled at Airbus’s Broughton site in Flintshire before being transported to final assembly lines in Toulouse, Hamburg, Mobile and Tianjin.

title: From Wright Brothers to AI: Aviation's Tech Evolution for Safer Skies - WebProNews
description:
The Wright brothers’ 1903 Flyer was a marvel of wood, wire and fabric, controlled by warping wings and a rudimentary elevator.
During World War II, analog computers helped with bomb aiming and navigation, but it was the post-war era that saw digital systems take root.
From Cables to Code: The Rise of Fly-by-Wire Systems Fly-by-wire systems represent a paradigm shift, where software mediates between pilot intent and aircraft response.
The FAA and EASA are updating frameworks to certify AI systems, ensuring they meet safety thresholds without stifling innovation.
Challenges like the stall in aircraft innovation, as per the Transport & Environment study, call for renewed focus on breakthroughs.
text:
Digital Skies: The Computational Conquest of Aviation

In the early days of aviation, pilots relied on mechanical ingenuity and sheer human skill to keep aircraft aloft. The Wright brothers’ 1903 Flyer was a marvel of wood, wire and fabric, controlled by warping wings and a rudimentary elevator. Fast-forward to today, and the cockpit has transformed into a high-tech command center where computers orchestrate everything from takeoff to landing. This shift didn’t happen overnight; it was a gradual infusion of digital technology that fundamentally altered how planes fly and how the industry operates. Drawing from historical accounts and recent innovations, we explore this evolution, crediting insights from sources like the Introduction to Aerospace Flight Vehicles by Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, which details the progression from basic flight vehicles to sophisticated systems.

Computers first entered aviation in subtle ways, often as tools for calculation rather than direct control. During World War II, analog computers helped with bomb aiming and navigation, but it was the post-war era that saw digital systems take root. By the 1950s, devices like the Bendix Central Air Data Computer used gears and synchros to compute airspeed and altitude, as noted in posts from X users discussing vintage aviation tech. These early systems laid the groundwork for more integrated roles, evolving from passive calculators to active participants in flight management.

The turning point came with the advent of fly-by-wire technology in the 1970s. Instead of mechanical linkages, electronic signals from the pilot’s controls are interpreted by computers, which then adjust flight surfaces. This innovation, pioneered in military jets like the F-16, allowed for unprecedented stability and efficiency. Commercial aviation soon followed, with Airbus introducing fly-by-wire in the A320 in 1988, a move that reduced weight and improved fuel economy.

From Cables to Code: The Rise of Fly-by-Wire Systems

Fly-by-wire systems represent a paradigm shift, where software mediates between pilot intent and aircraft response. Computers process inputs thousands of times per second, making micro-adjustments for smoother flights, as highlighted in a recent X post about modern airliners’ control surfaces. This technology not only enhances safety by preventing stalls but also enables envelope protection, where the system refuses commands that could endanger the plane.

Beyond control, computers revolutionized navigation. The inertial navigation systems of the 1960s gave way to GPS-integrated avionics in the 1990s, allowing precise positioning without ground-based aids. According to Centennial of Flight, these advancements ensured planes could reach destinations safely and on time, transforming global travel logistics.

The impact on the aviation industry extends to design and manufacturing. Computer-aided design (CAD) software has streamlined aircraft development, enabling simulations that test aerodynamics virtually before a single prototype is built. This has accelerated innovation cycles, reducing costs and time-to-market for new models.

Autopilot Evolution: From Gyroscopes to AI-Driven Guidance

Autopilots, once simple gyroscopic devices holding course, now incorporate artificial intelligence for complex tasks. Elmer Sperry’s 1914 invention evolved into systems that can manage entire flights, as described in the same Centennial of Flight resource. Modern autopilots integrate with flight management systems (FMS), optimizing routes for fuel efficiency and weather avoidance.

In recent years, AI has pushed boundaries further. A December 2025 X post recounted an incident where an autonomous system detected a pressurization issue at 23,000 feet, took control, communicated with air traffic control, and safely landed the plane. This level of autonomy hints at a future where pilots oversee rather than actively fly, raising questions about human roles in the cockpit.

The aviation sector has seen operational efficiencies soar thanks to these technologies. Airlines use big data analytics to predict maintenance needs, minimizing downtime. Spartan College outlines how such predictive maintenance has improved safety records, with fewer incidents due to mechanical failures.

Digital Twins and Simulation: Redefining Aircraft Design

One of the most profound changes is the use of digital twins—virtual replicas of physical aircraft that simulate real-world conditions. Engineers can test modifications in software environments, iterating designs rapidly. This approach, detailed in BAA Training’s blog on 2024 trends, has led to lighter, more efficient airframes, contributing to the industry’s push toward sustainability.

However, this reliance on computers isn’t without challenges. Recent IT meltdowns, like the Alaska Airlines grounding in late 2025, underscore vulnerabilities. As reported by NPR, these incidents highlight the need for robust backups and cybersecurity measures in an increasingly digital ecosystem.

On the innovation front, computers have enabled advancements in electric and hybrid propulsion. Simulations optimize battery placements and power distribution, paving the way for greener flights. The Transport & Environment analysis warns that without continued innovation, decarbonization goals could falter, emphasizing the role of computational modeling in breakthroughs.

Safety Enhancements Through Computational Intelligence

Safety has been the biggest beneficiary of computational integration. Systems like the Traffic Collision Avoidance System (TCAS) use radar and algorithms to prevent mid-air collisions, a technology that has saved countless lives since its 1990s rollout. Enhanced ground proximity warning systems (EGPWS) provide terrain awareness, further reducing accident rates.

In private aviation, emerging standards by 2030 may mandate predictive tech features, as per News Channel 3-12. These include AI-driven diagnostics that foresee failures, shifting from reactive to proactive safety protocols.

The military sector has driven many of these advancements. The U.S. Air Force’s upgrades, discussed in Simple Flying, balance legacy fleets with cutting-edge computing, incorporating AI for threat detection and autonomous operations.

Industry-Wide Transformations: Efficiency and Economics

Economically, computers have reshaped airline operations. Revenue management systems use algorithms to optimize ticket pricing, maximizing profits amid fluctuating demand. This data-driven approach, evolving since the 1980s, has made air travel more accessible while boosting carrier revenues.

Training has also been revolutionized. Flight simulators, powered by advanced graphics and physics engines, allow pilots to practice scenarios without risking lives or equipment. AOPA’s 1992 article on computers in aviation foresaw this trend, which has only intensified with virtual reality integrations.

Moreover, the push for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) relies on computational modeling to assess viability. Innovations like those in BAA Training’s list of game-changers include computer-optimized engines that reduce emissions, aligning with global environmental mandates.

Challenges and Future Horizons in Aviation Computing

Despite triumphs, the integration of computers brings hurdles. Cybersecurity threats loom large, with potential hacks disrupting critical systems. Industry insiders note that as planes become more connected, safeguarding digital infrastructure is paramount, echoing concerns from the NPR report on system failures.

Looking ahead, quantum computing could further transform aviation by solving complex optimization problems instantaneously, from route planning to material science for lighter composites. X posts from aviation engineers highlight ongoing developments, such as variable camber wings reprogrammed in flight, a concept Airbus explored in the 1980s.

The Boeing 737 MAX saga illustrates both potential and pitfalls. The MCAS system, introduced to handle engine placement changes, relied on software to maintain stability but led to tragedies when flaws emerged. A 2025 X post from an aircraft maintenance engineer explained how this small change amplified the need for rigorous software validation.

Pioneering Autonomy: Toward Pilotless Skies

Autonomy is the next frontier. Companies like Boeing and Airbus are testing unmanned cargo flights, leveraging AI for decision-making. The Amprius Technologies piece on future safety underscores how technology ensures reliable electric aircraft operations.

In urban air mobility, eVTOL vehicles depend on computers for navigation in crowded skies. These advancements promise to decongest roads and revolutionize short-haul travel, backed by simulations that predict traffic patterns.

Yet, regulatory bodies must keep pace. The FAA and EASA are updating frameworks to certify AI systems, ensuring they meet safety thresholds without stifling innovation.

Global Impacts and Ethical Considerations

On a global scale, computational advancements have democratized aviation in developing regions. Low-cost carriers use data analytics to expand routes, connecting remote areas. However, this raises ethical questions about job displacement, as automation reduces the need for human crews.

Diversity in aviation benefits from tech, with simulators making training more inclusive. Women and underrepresented groups gain access to high-fidelity practice, fostering a broader talent pool.

As we stand on the cusp of 2030, the fusion of computers and aviation continues to evolve. From the modular designs of the 747, analogized in an X post to software architecture, to AI-piloted emergencies, the trajectory is clear: computers aren’t just tools; they’re the very fabric of modern flight.

Sustaining Momentum in Technological Flight

To sustain this momentum, investment in R&D is crucial. Governments and private firms are pouring resources into next-gen computing, like edge AI for real-time decisions without cloud reliance.

Challenges like the stall in aircraft innovation, as per the Transport & Environment study, call for renewed focus on breakthroughs. Hybrid models combining human oversight with machine precision could mitigate risks.

Ultimately, the story of computers in aviation is one of relentless progress, turning what was once daring human endeavor into a symphony of silicon and sky. With each advancement, the industry soars higher, safer and more efficiently, promising a future where the impossible becomes routine.

title: Aemetis Receives Funds from the Sale of $17 million of Federal Clean Energy Tax Credits
description:
“This tax credit sale represents an important step in monetizing federal clean fuel transferable tax incentives and establishing a new recurring source of cash flow,” said Eric McAfee, Chairman and CEO of Aemetis.
The Company expects the amount of future 45Z tax credits to increase significantly based on production volume increases, increased credit values mandated by the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, and expected additional regulatory clarity.
In addition, Aemetis expects to generate a transferable Section 45C tax credit in 2026 worth $10.5 million, which has received approval from the IRS and the Department of Energy.
“With the completion of $95 million of ITC transactions and today’s first Section 45Z sale, we are executing our tax credit monetization strategy,” added McAfee.
Founded in 2006, Aemetis is operating and actively expanding a California biogas digester network and pipeline system to convert dairy waste gas into Renewable Natural Gas.
text:
CUPERTINO, Calif., Dec. 30, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Aemetis, Inc. (NASDAQ: AMTX), a renewable natural gas and renewable liquid fuels company focused on lower cost and reduced emissions products, today announced that its Aemetis Biogas LLC subsidiary received funds from the sale of $17 million of federal clean energy tax credits, including a Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit (PTC) and a Section 48 Investment Tax Credit (ITC).

The transaction included approximately $12 million for a Section 48 ITC generated from the construction of a dairy manure digester that produces biogas and approximately $5 million from a Section 45Z PTC generated from renewable natural gas production during 2025. Net cash proceeds from the transaction were approximately $15 million after transaction costs.

“This tax credit sale represents an important step in monetizing federal clean fuel transferable tax incentives and establishing a new recurring source of cash flow,” said Eric McAfee, Chairman and CEO of Aemetis. “This is our first sale of a Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit from dairy RNG, and we expect additional Section 45Z transactions in 2026 and future years from ongoing renewable natural gas production, along with additional Section 48 transactions from ongoing digester construction.”

The Section 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credit sold in this transaction was calculated under current Treasury guidance. The Company expects the amount of future 45Z tax credits to increase significantly based on production volume increases, increased credit values mandated by the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, and expected additional regulatory clarity.

In addition, Aemetis expects to generate a transferable Section 45C tax credit in 2026 worth $10.5 million, which has received approval from the IRS and the Department of Energy.

“With the completion of $95 million of ITC transactions and today’s first Section 45Z sale, we are executing our tax credit monetization strategy,” added McAfee. “We expect federal 45Z Clean Fuel Production Credits to be a rapidly growing source of operating cash flow to support the expansion of production and new job creation.”

About Aemetis

Headquartered in Cupertino, California, Aemetis is a renewable natural gas and renewable fuel company focused on the operation, acquisition, development, and commercialization of innovative technologies that replace petroleum products and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Founded in 2006, Aemetis is operating and actively expanding a California biogas digester network and pipeline system to convert dairy waste gas into Renewable Natural Gas. Aemetis owns and operates a 65 million gallon per year ethanol production facility in California’s Central Valley near Modesto that supplies about 80 dairies with animal feed. Aemetis owns and operates an 80 million gallon per year production facility on the East Coast of India producing high quality distilled biodiesel and refined glycerin. Aemetis is developing a sustainable aviation fuel plant and a CO2 sequestration project in California. For additional information about Aemetis, please visit www.aemetis.com.

title: Repsol Grows Iberian Network of Renewable Diesel Stations to Over 1,500 | Rigzone
description:
Repsol SA said Monday it now operates more than 1,500 retail stations for its Nexa Diesel in Spain and Portugal.
"Currently, more than 40 percent of the company’s network of service stations offers renewable fuel, demonstrating that decarbonizing transport with renewable liquid fuels is a viable solution for combustion engine vehicles.
"The 100 percent renewable Nexa Diesel, identified by its pink color, is Repsol's highest-end fuel.
At its Cartagena complex, Repsol operates what it says is the first facility in the Iberian Peninsula exclusively producing renewable fuels - sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel - at an industrial scale.
"To promote the use of sustainable aviation fuel, Repsol has signed major agreements with commercial airlines like Iberia, Ryanair, Vueling and Air Europa".
text:
Repsol SA said Monday it now operates more than 1,500 retail stations for its Nexa Diesel in Spain and Portugal.

"With this achievement, Repsol consolidates its position as the most relevant 100 percent renewable fuel networks in Europe, reaching more than 210 million liters sold so far this year", the Spanish energy company said in a press release.

"Currently, more than 40 percent of the company’s network of service stations offers renewable fuel, demonstrating that decarbonizing transport with renewable liquid fuels is a viable solution for combustion engine vehicles. These vehicles today represent 97 percent of the Spanish and European vehicle fleet, and 87 percent of sales in Spain so far this year.

"To meet the climate targets set by Spain and the European Union, it is essential to recognize the role of 100 percent renewable fuels to reducing CO2 emissions from combustion engines.

"The 100 percent renewable Nexa Diesel, identified by its pink color, is Repsol's highest-end fuel. It has an exclusive formulation that optimizes performance, extends engine life and is designed for all diesel engines. It is produced from raw materials of renewable origin and, with current technology, it already reduces the carbon footprint by up to 90 percent compared to the conventional fuel it replaces, thanks to the lower carbon intensity of the renewable fuel due to its organic origin".

At its Cartagena complex, Repsol operates what it says is the first facility in the Iberian Peninsula exclusively producing renewable fuels - sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel - at an industrial scale. Repsol announced the start-up of the waste-to-fuel project, which has a capacity of 250,000 metric tons a year, on March 4, 2024.

Earlier this year Repsol declared a "technological milestone" with the start of "industrial-scale" production of 100 percent renewable gasoline at its Tarragona complex.

"This new product, made entirely from renewable sources, is fully compatible with gasoline vehicles without the need for any modifications", Repsol said in an online statement October 8.

"Its use reduces net CO2 emissions by more than 70 percent compared to conventional gasoline.

"Nexa 95 Gasoline of 100 percent renewable origin - Repsol's highest-quality 95-octane product - is already available at 20 service stations in Spain, in the Madrid and Catalonia regions".

Repsol said it expects to deploy the product at 30 stations by yearend by expanding in other parts of the country including the cities of Bilbao, Tarragona, Valencia and Zaragoza.

The formulation was developed with Honeywell, according to Repsol.

It said it plans to build another plant to produce renewable road and maritime fuel at its Puertollano complex by 2026.

It said it has secured agreements to supply renewable fuels to heavy-duty road transport companies in Spain and Portugal including Scania, Grupo Sese, XPO, Serveto, Havi, Joanca, Carreras, Rhenus and Luis Simoes.

"The company also partners with Spanish passenger transport operators, such as Alsa and Avanza, and with maritime operators, such as Royal Caribbean", the statement said.

"To promote the use of sustainable aviation fuel, Repsol has signed major agreements with commercial airlines like Iberia, Ryanair, Vueling and Air Europa".

To contact the author, email jov.onsat@rigzone.com

description:

The agreement is the fifth order with Airbus, bringing the total number of Airbus aircraft ordered by CALC to 282, of which 203 are A320neo Family aircraft.
“CALC’s deep understanding of the market and what its customers demand is a solid endorsement of the A320neo Family.
The A320 Family is the world’s most popular single-aisle aircraft having won more than 19,000 orders globally.
